sense.def: the speed at which someone or something moves or does something
dictionaryExamples: a slow/fast pace
I don't like the pace of modern life.
These changes seem to be happening at too fast a pace.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am living at a much faster pace. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to move or develop at the same speed as someone or something else
dictionaryExamples: We have to keep pace with the changing times.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was first published a century ago and what amazes people most is that [it] keeps pace with the development of the country without leaving out references to our history and tradition. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to be careful not to do something too quickly so that you do not get too tired to finish it
dictionaryExamples: You must learn to pace yourself if you want to win.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When people are so old, they begin to pace themselves with some difficulties. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to walk around because you are worried or excited about something
dictionaryExamples: She paced back and forth outside the courtroom.
He kept pacing up and down, glancing at his watch.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was pacing up and down the entrance hall when finally he caught a glimpse of a person disappearing [a]round a corner. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to put your things into suitcases, boxes, etc. when you are going on vacation or leaving the place where you live
dictionaryExamples: We're leaving early tomorrow morning, so you'd better pack  tonight.
I haven't packed my clothes  yet.
She packed a small suitcase for the weekend.
These books need to be packed in those boxes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That day I picked up my tickets to India and came back home to pack my things, and of course I used my new suitcase. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: to collect all your things together when you have finished doing something
dictionaryExamples: Give me a  minute to pack up my things and then we can leave.
I'm ready to pack up and head home.
We need to pack everything up, but we can leave it here over the weekend.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They packed up all the equipment [and got ready] to leave, because most of them had to attend school the next day. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: a set of products or other things that are wrapped up together
dictionaryExamples: The information pack contains a brochure and a map.
a pack of gum/cards/cigarettes
I bought a pack of tissues to carry in my purse.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Almost 70% of people during a normal day eat at least two packs of chips and chocolate. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a group of animals that live together, especially those of the dog family
dictionaryExamples: a pack of wolves
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were like a pack of wolves, only puppies at the time though. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a box or other container that is shipped or brought to someone
dictionaryExamples: I need to get to the post office to send/mail this package.
A package came/was delivered for you today.
I'll put that magazine in the package with the other things I'm bringing you when I visit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was a call from the post office saying that the package he was waiting [for had arrived]. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a related group of things when they are offered together as a single unit
dictionaryExamples: a retirement/benefits package
The computer comes with a software package.
This ski package includes transportation, hotel, and a six-day lift pass.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Lastly, I need to know if all meals are included in your package. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a small bag or box that contains an amount of a particular thing
dictionaryExamples: a package of rice / spinach
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you really want some [candy], you should eat some, but not the whole package. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: very crowded
dictionaryExamples: The hall was packed.
The bus was packed with schoolchildren.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you want to meet and photograph the local people, the place to go is the Wednesday market. It is always packed with farmers, children, older people and so on. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: an agreement between two people or groups
dictionaryExamples: We have a pact never to talk about each other.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It became clear we had made a pact of silence. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: a piece of paper in a book, magazine, etc., or one side of a piece of paper
dictionaryExamples: Now turn to page 17 in your course book.
For details on how to enter the competition, see page 134.
The article appeared on the front page of today's newspaper.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It has 1095 pages and it is very big. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a part of a Web site that can be read on a computer screen
dictionaryExamples: I printed out a page about leg exercises.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The information is [on an] internet page, the [site] is www.art.com. For more information - visit the page. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: an unpleasant physical feeling caused by an injury or illness
dictionaryExamples: chest/stomach pains
Are you in  pain?
I felt a sharp pain in my foot.
He's been suffering various aches and pains for years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have a back pain and I couldn't sle[e]p last night. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Kurdish

sense.def: sadness or mental suffering caused by an unpleasant event
dictionaryExamples: Job losses in the auto industry are causing a lot of pain.
emotional/psychological pain
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He had caused me so much pain that I was unable to forgive him anymore. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to be annoying
dictionaryExamples: Having to keep the bikes in the house is such a pain.
My sister was being a real pain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was really a pain to pay that much for only a box of metal and a screen, but I think it is really going to help me. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

blocks.phrase: be a pain in the neck

sense.def: to be annoying
dictionaryExamples: My brother can be a real pain in the neck sometimes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He's adorable although sometimes he can really be a pain in the neck (don't tell him I wrote this.) Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: a sudden, short, strong pain
dictionaryExamples: I felt a sharp pain in my leg.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All that Tom remembered afterward was the loud noise of the braking t[i]res, a sharp pain in his legs and then darkness. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: causing physical pain
dictionaryExamples: A painful injury forced her to leave the game.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One of my [teeth] is very painful. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: making you feel sad or upset
dictionaryExamples: The old photograph brought back painful memories.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You know, I went through this painful decision just a few months ago, when I started working for a new company that pays me more, but gives me less time for my hobbies. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a colored liquid that you put on a surface such as a wall to decorate it, or that you use to produce a picture
dictionaryExamples: a can of paint
There were so many paints  to choose from that I couldn't decide which to buy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm going to use orange paint to paint my bedroom. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to produce a picture of something or someone using paint
dictionaryExamples: All these pictures were painted by local artists.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like [to] paint so my fav[o]rite [subject] is art. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: to cover a surface with paint in order to decorate it
dictionaryExamples: We painted the bedroom blue.
I've been painting all morning.
I need to paint over  these marks on the wall.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want your help to paint my room. Key English Test; A2; Telugu

sense.def: someone who paints pictures
dictionaryExamples: We are studying 19th century French painters.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have to bring information about some painters, [such] as Velazquez or Picasso. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a picture that someone has painted
dictionaryExamples: a painting by Caravaggio
The walls are covered with oil paintings.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are beautiful paintings painted by famous Iranian painters. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: the activity of painting pictures or painting surfaces
dictionaryExamples: I took a painting and drawing class.
When we bought the house, we had to do a lot of painting and redecorating.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like reading, painting, and I like swimming too. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: two people who are doing something together
dictionaryExamples: I'd like you to do this exercise in pairs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We [do] dialogues in pairs or between other students. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: two things that look the same and  that are used together
dictionaryExamples: a pair of shoes/gloves
I can't find a matching pair of socks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I got a pair of earrings from my parents. Key English Test; A2; Farsi

sense.def: something that is made of two parts that are joined together
dictionaryExamples: a pair of scissors/glasses
a pair of jeans
He packed two pairs of trousers and four shirts.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Don't forget to bring an old T-shirt and a pair of jeans. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: soft, loose clothing that is worn in bed and consists of a shirt and pants
dictionaryExamples: I need a new pair of pajamas.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, bring old clothes or pajamas. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: a very large building where a king, queen or president lives
dictionaryExamples: a royal/presidential palace
While in Istanbul, we saw the Blue Mosque and the Topkapi Palace.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know some places [in London] like Big Ben and Buckingham Palace. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a tall tree with long leaves at the top that grows in hot countries
dictionaryExamples: They sat beneath a palm tree.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Santorini was a picturesque island, with many rural areas, sensational deserted beaches with palm trees. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: the inside surface of your hand
dictionaryExamples: I cut the palm of my hand on the rock.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When the concert was over, everybody in the audience was on their feet clapping (until their palms were sweaty) and asking for [an]  encore. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: a round, metal container with a handle and usually a lid, that is used for cooking food
dictionaryExamples: Heat the milk in the small pan.
This dishwasher even washes pots and pans.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [At this restaurant,] you cook the food in the pan by yourself. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: a metal container used for cooking food in an oven
dictionaryExamples: cake pans
a baking/roasting pan

sense.def: a thin, flat food made from flour, milk, and egg mixed together and cooked in a pan
dictionaryExamples: We had pancakes with maple syrup.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can't come to Holland without trying the Dutch pancakes, which are much better than the English ones. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: a group of people who are chosen to discuss something or make a decision about something
dictionaryExamples: a panel of experts
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We can justify our opinion about the quality by referring to the extremely varied and constructive social program, which is also organi[z]ed by a panel of experts, sociologists and psychologists. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a flat, rectangular piece of wood, metal, etc. that forms the surface of a door, wall, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The walls were made from wooden panels.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The glass roof provides excellent lighting, and the wood panels on the walls certainly contribute to the co[z]y atmosphere. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a sudden, strong feeling of worry or fear that makes you unable to think or behave calmly
dictionaryExamples: a state of panic
Panic spread through the crowd as the wind and rain grew worse.
Carmel was in a panic about her exam.
I could hear the panic in his voice
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So in a state of panic she decided to take a taxi. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to suddenly feel so worried or frightened that you cannot think or behave calmly, or to make someone feel this way
dictionaryExamples: Don't panic! We've got plenty of time.
The sound of gunfire panicked the crowd.
The boss panics over the budget every month.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: David started thinking that a thief may have come [in]to their house. "Don't panic", he told his wife. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: women's underwear which covers the bottom
dictionaryExamples: a  pair of panties
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The whole audience could see the color of my panties. How embarrassing! I could just die. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: a piece of clothing that covers the lower part of the body and has a separate part for each leg
dictionaryExamples: a pair of brown pants
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And please can you wear a white T-shirt and blue pants? Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: a piece of women's clothing made of thin material that covers body below the waist, including the legs
dictionaryExamples: She bought a new pair of pantyhose.

sense.def: thin, flat material used for writing or drawing on, covering things in, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a piece/sheet of paper
She works on paper  because she hates computers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [The] teacher will give us paper so don't worry! Key English Test; A2; Greek

sense.def: a newspaper
dictionaryExamples: a daily/weekly/local/national paper
The photo was on the front page of all the papers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hey Jo, Yesterday I [saw] an advertisement for a job in a local paper: it said that if you like pets, you can become a dog-sitter for three days a week. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: a piece of writing about a particular subject
dictionaryExamples: I have a ten-page paper due for my history class next Monday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I wrote a paper about children in Africa - their feelings concerning the Civil war. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: the part of a job that involves producing reports, writing letters, organizing information, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Many office jobs involve a lot of unnecessary paperwork.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As I am good [at] paperwork, I think [it would] be great if I [could] help you in the office. First Certificate in English; B2; Bulgarian

sense.def: a large piece of special cloth used to cause someone or something it is attached to drop slowly and safely from an aircraft to the ground
dictionaryExamples: He used a parachute to jump to safety.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Those minutes, up in the air, feeling the wind in my face, were fantastic... and then I was terrified when I couldn't open the parachute! First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a line of people or vehicles that moves through a public place as a way of celebrating an occasion
dictionaryExamples: the Labor Day / Memorial Day parade
The school band will be in the Thanksgiving Day parade.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The festival starts with a huge opening parade. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: a typical example or model of something
dictionaryExamples: Career women are establishing a new paradigm of work and family life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Science is supposed to be a rational, factual matter, but especially in this field when you express a view or do research into topics which go against the ruling paradigm, it's difficult. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: a perfect place or situation
dictionaryExamples: a tropical paradise
a shoppers' paradise
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our online catalogue is a true shopping paradise. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: a situation that seems very strange or impossible because of two opposite qualities or facts
dictionaryExamples: It's a curious paradox that drinking a lot of water can make you feel thirsty.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They usually have less money and more time to spend their money in. This is a paradox. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: seeming very strange or impossible because of two opposite qualities or facts
dictionaryExamples: a paradoxical position/situation
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Women are entering the labor market and, paradoxical though it may seem, they still are, in many cases, in charge of the house. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: a part of a text that begins on a new line and usually contains several sentences
dictionaryExamples: Write a paragraph describing the garden.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I [made] many mistakes when I read [the] paragraph. Preliminary English Test; B1; Burmese

sense.def: similar and happening at the same time
dictionaryExamples: Parallel experiments are being conducted in both countries.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The diary was a dimensional portal to a parallel world he called Wonderland. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: a similarity
dictionaryExamples: There are a number of parallels between our two situations.
People are drawing parallels between the two cases.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It magnificently establishes a parallel between the tragic demise of an outstanding Ibo man named Okonkwo and the cultural as well as religious downfall of his entire clan and generally the disintegration of African tribal life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: more important than anything else
dictionaryExamples: Safety, of course, is paramount.
Communication is of paramount importance.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The attitude[s] towards creating their own styles differ - some perceive it simply as a matter of taste, for others this visual reflection of personality is of paramount importance. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: your mother or father
dictionaryExamples: I'm going to meet Richard's parents for the first time this weekend.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like this place because my parents live there. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Czech

sense.def: either of two curved symbols put around a word, phrase or sentence in a piece of writing to show that what is between them should be considered as separate from the main part
dictionaryExamples: Biographical information is included in parentheses.

sense.def: a large area of grass and trees in a city or town, where people can walk and enjoy themselves
dictionaryExamples: Central Park
Hyde Park
We go running in the park.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The park is near my house. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese

sense.def: to leave a vehicle in a particular place for a period of time
dictionaryExamples: Where did you park?
You can park your car over there.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the way to the hospital, I decided to buy a present so I parked my car and bought some yellow flowers. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: leaving a vehicle in a particular place for a period of time
dictionaryExamples: a parking space/spot
street/underground parking
Some people aren't good at parallel parking.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can't find a parking place when you need one and cars are a problem because of the pollution. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: the places where a vehicle can be left
dictionaryExamples: There's plenty of parking near the theater.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The next suggestion connected with this park is not to build any parking for cars. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: an area for parking cars
dictionaryExamples: I put the car in the parking lot.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The bad thing is that it is located in a street where there are a lot of other restaurants so the parking lot is very small. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: in some countries, a group of people who make the laws for the country
dictionaryExamples: On Tuesday the country's parliament voted to establish its own army.
She was elected to Parliament in 1997.

sense.def: a tropical bird with a curved beak and colorful feathers which can be taught to copy what people say
dictionaryExamples: We saw parrots flying wild in the jungle.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Send my regards to your family and to your lovely parrot too. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: a piece that combines with other pieces to form the whole of something
dictionaryExamples: Which part of Buenos Aires do you live in?
They learn about the different parts of the body.
Fresh fruit and vegetables are an important part of a healthy diet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's the most beautiful part of Poland. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: some but not all of a thing
dictionaryExamples: Elsa spent part of the day shopping.
Part of the problem is their lack of money.
Free parking is offered as part of the hotel package.
It's all part of growing up.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [A] computer is part of you[r] life. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Ukrainian

sense.def: a character in a movie or play
dictionaryExamples: He plays the part of the father in the movie version.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The main actor played the part of John, a poor man that becomes rich winning a prize. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to be involved in an activity with other people
dictionaryExamples: She doesn't usually take part in class activities.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last month when we took part in a dance competition, I couldn't imagine that we were able to win, but we did. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to be one of the people or things that are involved in an event or situation
dictionaryExamples: People forget to wash their hands and that plays a part in spreading colds and flu.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Technology plays an important part in this situation, because I don't think that adults are playing computer games for Batman or Spiderman, for example, but for the special effec[t]s and the gra[phics]. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a piece of a machine or vehicle
dictionaryExamples: aircraft parts
spare parts
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were lucky to have some spare parts with us and finally Tom managed to repair [his car]. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: mostly or usually
dictionaryExamples: I enjoyed it for the most part.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, for the most part, people have to use computers in their jobs. International English Language Testing System; C1; French

blocks.phrase: on the part of sb; on sb's part

sense.def: done or experienced by someone
dictionaryExamples: This is a major sacrifice on the part of the unions.
The accident was caused by carelessness on the instructor's part.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It seems that international sports competitions have always tended to attract a great amount of interest on the part of the media and have consistently been popular with sports fans the world over. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Bulgarian

sense.def: partly
dictionaryExamples: He is in part to blame for the accident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Technology is in part to blame. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: most of a period of time
dictionaryExamples: It took the better part of the afternoon to put those shelves up.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Major sporting competitions have been around for the better part of 2500 years, ever since the original Olympic Games were held in ancient Greece. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: If something is part and parcel of an experience, it is a necessary part of that experience and cannot be avoided.
dictionaryExamples: Stress is part and parcel of the job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is true to a certain extent as food is often part and parcel of traditional rituals. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: If two sides of something part, they become separated, and if you part them, you make them separate.
dictionaryExamples: Slowly her lips parted and she smiled.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There we were, three rather disheveled young men with a stench that parted a path for us like Moses did the Red Sea. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: If two people part, or if one person parts from another, they leave each other.
dictionaryExamples: That summer, after six years of marriage, we parted.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was on my seventeenth birthday that he gave me a little blue and shimmering box, but said I couldn't open it until the day we parted. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: not complete
dictionaryExamples: The general has ordered a partial withdrawal of troops from the area.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In conclusion, I am [very] disappointed and therefore, I believe that I am entitled to a partial refund. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: not completely
dictionaryExamples: partially cooked
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Building a parking area outside the city cent[e]r would partially solve this problem. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: someone who is involved in an activity
dictionaryExamples: All participants finishing the race will receive a medal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was one of the participants who helped a charity organization to raise money for the local hospital. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: to take part in or become involved in an activity
dictionaryExamples: She never participates in any of our discussions, does she?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So, all the students can participate in different activities. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a very small piece of something
dictionaryExamples: particles of dust
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They got their hands on some anthrax bacteria, grew them in petri dishes and with all her knowledge in biology managed to make anthrax spores. Her friends ground the clumps of spores into fine particles. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: especially, or more than usual
dictionaryExamples: Your ideas are  particularly helpful.
She didn't seem particularly interested.
"Was the food good?" "Not particularly."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I particularly enjoyed swimming in your new swimming pool. Preliminary English Test; B1; Georgian

sense.def: to some extent, but not completely
dictionaryExamples: The house is partly owned by her father.
He was partly responsible for the error.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I suggest you spend your time partly in the countryside and partly in a city. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: someone who you do something with, for example playing a sport, dancing, or working in class
dictionaryExamples: Now discuss your ideas with your partner.
I was Andy's partner for the tennis tournament.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is my best partner when we are play[ing] games [o]n the internet. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: someone who you live with and have a sexual relationship with
dictionaryExamples: Partners are not invited to the office party.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mike had been my partner for 3 years. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: one of two or more people who own a business
dictionaryExamples: junior/senior partner
My business partner handles international sales.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Don't spend the evenings with your business partners, but with your women, children and friends. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: when two people or organizations work together to achieve something
dictionaryExamples: She's gone into partnership with someone she used to work with.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I really need the money you're offering, mainly to set up that kindergar[t]en school I've told you about, where I would work in partnership with a friend. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: If you work part-time or do part-time work, you work for only some of the day or the week.
dictionaryExamples: a part-time job
He works part-time as a waiter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can't afford to buy it so I'll look for a part-time job. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: a social event where people enjoy themselves by talking, eating, drinking, and dancing
dictionaryExamples: a birthday party
We're having a party to celebrate Jack's new job.
Peter gives/throws really wild parties.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have the [sp]ace to invite my friends to [a] party. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: an organization of people who share the same political beliefs and try to win elections
dictionaryExamples: a political party
the Republican/Democratic Party
He lost the Republican primary but may run as a third party candidate.
Members of his own party voted against the bill.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He organi[z]ed a political party called "Kuo Min Tang of China" and started his revolution to overthrow the Chinese monarchy. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to succeed in a test or examination
dictionaryExamples: I passed my driving test!
I know you'll pass all your exams.
Theo passed the FCE when he was 14.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I [hope] you pass the exam. Key English Test; A2; Farsi

sense.def: to go past something or someone
dictionaryExamples: I passed him on the stairs this morning.
Cars kept passing us on the highway.
If you pass a grocery store on the way back, could you pick up some milk?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I started to cros[s] the street and then a car passed. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to go in a particular direction
dictionaryExamples: A low flying plane passed over the stadium.
We passed by your house our way home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then we passed through the quiet co[u]ntryside. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: to give something to someone
dictionaryExamples: Could you pass the salt, please?
Gerald passed me a note./Gerald passed a note to me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For [me to] cover [the] work, can you pass [it] to my friend Jittanun. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: If a period of time passes, it happens.
dictionaryExamples: Has ten minutes passed yet?
We had to wait, but the time passed quickly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Five minutes passed and he didn't come, so I decided to go back inside. Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek

sense.def: to spend time doing something
dictionaryExamples: We passed the time reading and  swimming.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What's more, I would have to read to pass the time! First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to  officially approve of something and make it into a law or rule
dictionaryExamples: The state assembly passed a law restricting the sale of guns.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope the government will pass a law which could [control] all these sort of things. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: If a feeling passes, it goes away.
dictionaryExamples: I know he's angry now but it'll pass.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My soul and my mind are frozen. I know that will pass. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to be more than a particular level
dictionaryExamples: Donations have passed the one million mark.

sense.def: in sports, to throw or kick a ball to someone else
dictionaryExamples: Edwards passes to Brinkworth.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Worth passed the ball to Earvin "Magic" Johnson, and with two players disturbing him, he sh[o]t a three-pointer that went in nicely. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

blocks.phrasalVerb: pass around sth or pass sth around

sense.def: to offer something to each person in a group of people
dictionaryExamples: Would you pass the sandwiches around?

sense.def: to die
dictionaryExamples: She passed away peacefully in her sleep.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was said his father was very ill and his doctor had said his father could pass away in a few months. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

blocks.phrasalVerb: pass on sth or pass sth on

sense.def: to tell someone something that another person has told you
dictionaryExamples: Will you pass the message on to Edward?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Lucy asked me to pass on greetings to you. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: to give something to someone else
dictionaryExamples: Could you pass the book on to Lara when you finished with it?

sense.def: to become unconscious
dictionaryExamples: I passed out from the heat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When she felt a hand on her right shoulder, she passed out. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: an official document or ticket that allows you to do something
dictionaryExamples: a bus/train pass
a boarding pass
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can buy [a] one-day bus pass and you could visit many monuments and pictures[qu]e places. Preliminary English Test; B1; Serbian

sense.def: in sports, when you throw or kick a ball to someone else
dictionaryExamples: That was a great pass!

sense.def: a long, narrow space that connects one room or place to another
dictionaryExamples: A passage between the buildings leads to the parking lot.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We saw a big house but it was old and locked. We found a secret passage between the trees and we got inside. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a short part of a book, speech, or piece of music
dictionaryExamples: Several passages from the book were printed in a national newspaper before it was published.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She would read a passage for us every night before [we fell] asleep. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the movement or progress from one stage or place to another
dictionaryExamples: It's a difficult passage from boyhood to manhood.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Work has always been a fundamental question in the life of man since the iron-age, it marks the passage from youth to adulthood and for most of us it can be a turning point. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: someone who is traveling in a vehicle but is not controlling it
dictionaryExamples: airline/train/car passengers
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We asked some other passengers but nobody had seen our suitcases. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: a very powerful feeling, for example of attraction, love, hate, anger or other emotion
dictionaryExamples: She saw the passion in his eyes.
Football fans show a lot of passion for the game.
Politics and philosophy were his lifelong passions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Surfing is my passion. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: when you like something very much
dictionaryExamples: a passion for baseball
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I always had a passion for writing and for 3 years I wrote many articles in my school magazine. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: having very strong feelings or emotions
dictionaryExamples: a passionate speech
a passionate kiss
A passionate appeal for help came from several relief organizations.
Joe is passionate about baseball.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I wrote a passionate article about how to protect our environment. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: in a way that shows strong feelings or emotions
dictionaryExamples: I walked into the room and found them arguing passionately.
Ann has always believed passionately in women's rights.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We kissed each other passionately like the firs[t] time, and then we sat down. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: an official document, often a small book, that you need to enter or leave a country
dictionaryExamples: passport control
a passport photo
Many refugees have arrived at the border without passports.
Don't forget to bring your passport - you need to show it when you cross the border.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have left my passport in the living room. Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: something that allows you to achieve something else
dictionaryExamples: Education is a passport to a better life.

sense.def: a secret word that allows you to do something, such as use your computer
dictionaryExamples: Type in your password.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It wasn't me, [it] was my brother who stole my password. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used to say what the time is when it is a particular number of minutes after an hour
dictionaryExamples: It's 5/10/a quarter/20/25/half past three.
I've got to leave at twenty past or I'll be late.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The class started the 2nd of June at half past five. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: in or to a position that is further than a particular point
dictionaryExamples: I live on Stanton Street, just past the post office.
Three boys went past us on bikes.
Was that Peter who just ran past wearing bright yellow shorts?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Turn right past the store and turn left ok? Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: beyond a particular age or further than a particular point
dictionaryExamples: This milk is past its expiration date.
She's past the age where she needs a babysitter.

sense.def: having happened or existed before now
dictionaryExamples: past relationships
I know this from past experience.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like the place because it has [nice] people, music and all sorts of things [about] past events. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used to refer to a period of time before and until the present
dictionaryExamples: I've moved twice in the past ten years.
It's been raining for the past three days.
He was the fifth climber to die on these mountains over the past two days.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For the past four years I have been playing tennis and I have also done some courses about painting. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the form of the verb which is used to show what happened in the past
dictionaryExamples: The past of "change" is "changed."

sense.def: the time before the present and all the things that happened then
dictionaryExamples: the distant/recent past
In the past, more travel was by train.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the past, we were best friends. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: all of the things that someone has done in their life
dictionaryExamples: I knew nothing about his past.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After the film, we went to a restaurant called Adriano, and as the weather was cool, we had a glass of wine and started asking [about] each other's past. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a food that is made from flour, water and sometimes eggs, and comes in many different shapes
dictionaryExamples: Spaghetti, lasagne, ravioli and cannelloni are all types of pasta.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Usually we eat potatoes with some meat, or rice, or pasta with nice sausage. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Spanish

sense.def: an activity that you enjoy doing when you are not working
dictionaryExamples: Watching hockey is one of her favorite pastimes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For many people music is merely a hobby or pastime, for others it's a job, and for yet others music is an important part of life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a mixture of flour, fat, and water that is cooked, usually used to cover or contain other food
dictionaryExamples: I made some pastry for the pie.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The most popular sweet dish is called "Apfelstrudel", which is a bit of potato pastry filled with apples and nuts. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: a small cake that is made with pastry
dictionaryExamples: We had coffee and pastries.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They don't want to miss their sweet pastries and "Sacher tortes", [which] Austria is famous for. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: to touch a person or animal with a flat hand in a gentle, friendly way
dictionaryExamples: She stopped to pat the dog.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All my mother's friends would come to our house, pat me on the head and say smiling: "Isn't she precious?!" Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a small area that is different from the area around it
dictionaryExamples: a bald patch
There are icy patches on the road.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All my senses were sharpened, I could clearly see the tired smile of the bass-guitarist and wet patches on his T-shirt. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: a piece of material that you use to cover a hole in your clothes or in other material
dictionaryExamples: He had leather patches sewn on the elbows of his jacket.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And my mother cherishes her family [heirloom] handed down for generations - it's a quilt with s[e]wn patches on it, representing what each of the women's strongest passion was. My mother s[e]wed on her patch presenting her childhood fascination of The Beatles. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a small area of land used for a particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: a cabbage/vegetable patch
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My father had a big allotment with different vegetables like turnips, beet, etc., etc. [At] my house there was also a vegetable patch. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a difficult time
dictionaryExamples: I think their marriage is going through a bad patch.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We all went through a rough patch when my mother turned out to have cancer. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to repair a hole in a piece of clothing or other material by sewing a piece of material over it
dictionaryExamples: to patch your sweater
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There were also clothes to be men[d]ed and patched, socks to be darned. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to try to improve your relationship with someone after you have had an argument
dictionaryExamples: Has he managed to patch things up with her?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then in bed I asked my goddess to make my parents patch up their quarrel. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: a long, narrow track between one place and another
dictionaryExamples: a bike path
This is the path to the cliffs.
They followed the path until they came to a gate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Follow it and you'll see a path which goes to the Park. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: a set of actions over a period of time, especially ones which lead to a goal or result
dictionaryExamples: a career path
The path to success has many difficulties.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maybe you could talk about your latest book "Murder on Avenue B" or about your path to fame. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: the direction that a person or vehicle moves in
dictionaryExamples: a flight path
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you obviously cannot change the flight path towards or away from the airfield then we have to take alternative action. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Maltese

sense.def: to meet someone, especially by accident
dictionaryExamples: Mike has moved away and I doubt he'll ever cross my path again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are all sociali[z]ed by our peers, family and other people who cross our path at one time or another. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: showing no skill, effort, or bravery
dictionaryExamples: He made a rather pathetic attempt to apologize.
You're too frightened to speak to her? Come on, that's pathetic!
It was a pathetic performance and the team lost badly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sometimes it seems to me that the whole world ha[s] a book of platitudes, which everybody uses in order to communicate. I find it rather pathetic. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: sad and weak
dictionaryExamples: Four times the pathetic little creature fell to the ground.
The refugees were a pathetic sight - starving, frightened and cold.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On Saturday morning, I see them sleeping rough under the bridges, a pathetic sight. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: the quality of being able to stay calm and not get angry, especially when something takes a long time
dictionaryExamples: You have to have such a lot of patience when you're dealing with kids.
In the end, I lost my patience and shouted at her.
He's a good teacher, but he doesn't have much patience with the slower pupils.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have patience with animals and care [for] them with love.  First Certificate in English; B2; Serbian

sense.def: someone who is being treated by a doctor, nurse, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a cancer patient
I'm a patient of Dr. Stephens -- could I make an appointment to see her?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Secondly, I don't think that we can use the bus to carry a patient to the hospital in case of emergency. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: having patience
dictionaryExamples: Dinner will be ready in half an hour - just be patient!
Be patient with her - she's very young.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is very patient with us and she tries to explain everything in detail for better understanding. Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak

sense.def: in a patient way
dictionaryExamples:
There was a line of people waiting patiently for the bus to
                         arrive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She made her way slowly to the waiting room and patiently waited for the train to arrive. First Certificate in English; B2; Azerbaijani

sense.def: a design of lines, shapes, colors, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The carpet was very old and had an unusual pattern.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my country now legging[s are] the new fashion. Some wear [ones] with stripes, or the black [ones] also ha[ve] a zebra pattern. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: a particular way that something is often done or repeated
dictionaryExamples: The pattern of family life has changed over the years.
Many behavior(al) patterns have been identified in this study of chimpanzees.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If the alarm-clock had worked, everything would have follow[ed] its usual pattern but this time I woke up too late. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a drawing, shape or set of instructions that helps you to make something
dictionaryExamples: a dress/knitting pattern
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Approximately three years ago I started to sew my own clothes. I always buy a pattern and follow every instruction given. First Certificate in English; B2; Norwegian

sense.def: a short period in which something such as a sound or an activity is stopped before starting again
dictionaryExamples: There will be a brief pause in the concert while the piano is moved into place.
After a long, awkward pause someone asked a question.
She spoke for three quarters of an hour without a pause.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to correct the journalist [by] saying to him that RADIANT played for 1 hour without any pause. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to stop doing something for a short time
dictionaryExamples: He paused for a moment.
She paused to catch her breath back and hurried away.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After a while, she pulled herself together and paused for a minute. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to make a CD, DVD, etc. stop for a short time by pressing a button
dictionaryExamples: Can you pause the movie for a few minutes? I'll be right back.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I paused the video I was watching, wondering what that [knocking sound] was. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: the hard, artificial surface covering a road
dictionaryExamples: One lane of the highway will be closed over the weekend to repair cracked pavement.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In a second step, we can ask the mayor to put pavement [o]n the streets. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: the foot of an animal that has claws or nails, such as a cat, dog or bear
dictionaryExamples: I found paw prints in the kitchen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My cat is only 2 years old. She is very beautiful with her long [b]ushy tail and soft paws. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to give money to someone for something you are buying or using, or because you owe them money
dictionaryExamples: Helena paid for the meal.
He paid $200 for the tickets.
Do you want to pay by cash or card?
Did you pay the telephone bill?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I [don't] have to pay. It's free. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Urdu

sense.def: to give someone money for the work that they do
dictionaryExamples: She gets paid twice a month.
Accounting may be boring but at least it pays well.
Most of these women are very poorly paid and work in terrible conditions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Those are the first thing[s] I am going to buy when I get paid. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to watch, listen to, or think about something carefully
dictionaryExamples: You weren't paying attention, were you?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Larry is a very distracted boy. Everybody says that he should pay attention to what he is doing. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

blocks.phrase: pay sb/sth a visit or pay a visit to sb/sth

sense.def: to visit a person or place, usually for a short time
dictionaryExamples: We thought we'd pay Sam a visit while we're in Atlanta.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: P.S: Wherever you decide to go, do not fail to pay me a visit! First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to tell someone that you admire something about them
dictionaryExamples: He paid her several compliments about her painting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His companions always pay him compliments on his [piano] playing. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to suffer because of something bad you have done
dictionaryExamples: He's certainly paying for his mistakes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He hurried back to the castle and was so disgusted with her that he had her locked forever in a cell, to pay for what she had done. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to accept the unpleasant results of what you have done
dictionaryExamples: If you abuse your body now, you'll pay the price when you're older.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When all is said and done, do contemporary sports events pose an advantage to athletes pursuing their physical excellence? I would dare to say no, unless he, or increasingly she, is prepared to pay the price in becoming a ready-made product for public consumption. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: to thank someone or say that you admire someone or something, especially in public
dictionaryExamples: He paid tribute to his former teacher.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although it may not seem [so], this is just a way of paying tribute to Mahatma Gand[h]i, since he always encouraged people to return to their traditions and c[ustom]s. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

blocks.phrasalVerb: pay back sb/sth or pay sb/sth back

sense.def: to pay someone the money that you owe them
dictionaryExamples: If you can buy the book for me, I'll pay you back tomorrow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I put money on the table. If it is not enough, please tell me [and] I'll pay you back. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

blocks.phrasalVerb: pay off sth or pay sth off

sense.def: to pay all of the money that you owe
dictionaryExamples: I've paid off the loan.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I promise you I'll pay off all my phone bills. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: If something that you have done to try to achieve something pays off, it is successful.
dictionaryExamples: All your hard work has obviously paid off!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think people shouldn't underestimate the importance of books and I am sure it will finally pay off! First Certificate in English; B2; Czech

sense.def: the money you receive for doing a job
dictionaryExamples: Did you get a pay increase?
It's a nice job but the pay is terrible.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The pay is good, but have you [got] a car to get everywhere? Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: describes something to be paid
dictionaryExamples: Rent is payable monthly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were informed by you that there would be nothing extra to be paid but in fact several admission fees were payable. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: If a check is payable to a person, that person's name is written on the check and the money will be paid to them.
dictionaryExamples: Checks should be made payable to "Express Enterprises."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please make your che[ck] payable to "Mr. C. ZHANG." Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: an amount of money paid
dictionaryExamples: You can pay in full now or twelve monthly payments.
When is the first payment due?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now people can buy or sell things from their home. [T]hey don't have to go to the bank, if they want [to] make a payment. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: the act of paying
dictionaryExamples: They will accept payment by credit card.
Usually we ask for payment on receipt of the goods.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Fina[l]ly, we employees have been facing delays on payment of our wages. Skills for Life (Level 1); B2; Portuguese

sense.def: personal computer
dictionaryExamples: The price of a PC has been falling.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to sell my old PC. [I]t's 2 years old. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: a round green seed, several of which grow in a pod, eaten as a vegetable
dictionaryExamples: frozen/dried peas
pea soup
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had a fish meal with some vegetables: peas, beans, carrots and lettuce. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: calm and quiet
dictionaryExamples: You'll need peace and quiet to study.
He says he's at peace when he's walking in the mountains.
Go away and let us to finish our dinner in peace.
There'll be no peace until she gets what she wants.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I saw a lot of primitive people who live in peace with the rainforest. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: when there is no war, violence or arguing
dictionaryExamples: peace talks
a peace agreement
Now that the war is over may there be alasting peace between our nations.
She's very good at keeping (the) peace within the family.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: World peace was being threat[e]ned by the Gulf War, major countries were taking sides and preparing to fight each other, millions of lives were in danger but no one seemed to care enough. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a feeling that you do not need to worry about anything
dictionaryExamples: We lock our doors and windows at night for peace of mind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After all, successfully earning your living guarantees peace of mind. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: quiet and calm
dictionaryExamples: a peaceful afternoon/place
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This village is in a peaceful location with [a] sandy beach. Preliminary English Test; B1; Bulgarian

sense.def: without violence
dictionaryExamples: a peaceful demonstration/protest
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Leipzig is well-known in the world because of the begin[ning] of the peaceful revolution in 1989 in Germany. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: in a peaceful way
dictionaryExamples: He died peacefully at home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There were a beautiful bride and a handsome bridegroom who were sleeping peacefully with smiles on their faces. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: a round fruit with sweet yellow flesh that has a lot of juice, a slightly furry red and yellow skin and a large seed in its center
dictionaryExamples: Would you like peaches and cream for dessert?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I enjoy eating cool summer fruit, such as melon, water-melon, peaches and apricots. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: the top of a mountain, or the mountain itself
dictionaryExamples: snow-covered peaks
It is one of the most difficult peaks to climb.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can walk or ride a horse to reach the peak. Preliminary English Test; B1; Indonesian

sense.def: the highest level or value of something
dictionaryExamples: peak travel times
Air travel reaches a peak during August.
Here we see an athlete at the peak of her career.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The situation gets worse, especially [during] peak hours, when people go to work or school and when they return home. First Certificate in English; B2; Slovene

sense.def: an oval-shaped nut with  a thin brown shell
dictionaryExamples: peanut oil
salted/dry-roast(ed) peanuts
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I went to the supermarket where I bought some peanuts, cheese dip and a bottle [of] soda. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: an oval-shaped, pale green or yellow fruit
dictionaryExamples: We had a delicious dessert of pears in cider.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  I want to buy melons, tomatoes, apples and pears. Key English Test; A2; Catalan

sense.def: a poor person who works on the land, usually in a poor country
dictionaryExamples: a peasant farmer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Monteiro made a lot of trips to see and speak with fishermen and peasants. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: unusual and strange, sometimes in an unpleasant way
dictionaryExamples: She has the most peculiar ideas.
What a peculiar smell!
It's peculiar that they didn't tell us they were going away.
He has a peculiar way of talking.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yesterday I had a birthday and my friend Pat suggested that I should visit a fortune-teller. We went along to visit the most peculiar woman I have ever met in my life. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: belonging to or relating to a particular person or thing
dictionaryExamples: Her accent is peculiar to the region.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The warm atmosphere obliterated every trace of shyness peculiar to the somewhat inhibited Swedes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: a part of a machine that you press with your foot to operate or move the machine
dictionaryExamples: the brake pedal
This sewing machine is operated with a foot pedal.
He stood up on the pedals of his bike to get extra power as he rode up the hill.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It has a comfortable seat, big pedals and a [w]onderful inscription "RIDER". First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a person who is walking and not traveling in a vehicle
dictionaryExamples: a pedestrian crossing
Many streets are reserved for cyclists and pedestrians.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There aren't cars in the city, because the roads are only for pedestrians. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to remove the skin of fruit and vegetables
dictionaryExamples: Peel and chop the onions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are a family of four and everybody peels vegetables, does [the] washing-up and makes coffee. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: If a layer or covering peels, it slowly comes off, and if you peel a layer or covering, you remove it slowly and carefully.
dictionaryExamples: The posters were peeling away from the damp walls.
Peel off the backing strip and press the label down firmly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The building that housed the school was run down, with paint peeling off the walls and all the furniture like chairs and tables falling apart. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to watch carefully for someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Keep your eyes peeled, he should be here any minute.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Ever since, I try to keep my eyes peeled for anything similar. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: someone who is the same age, or who has the same social position or abilities as other members of a group
dictionaryExamples: Most teenagers want to be accepted by their peers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It could be a little boring, especially when you are young and all you want is to be with your peers, stay out [all night], get back early in the morning and sleep until afternoon. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to look carefully or with difficulty
dictionaryExamples: She peered at me over her glasses.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Slightly opening the door, she peered inside: a small [shaft] of moonlight passing through the [curtain] lit the small room: there was nobody inside, and the phone on the old desk was silent. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: the influence of people who are of a similar age or in a similar situation to you
dictionaryExamples: When it comes to fashion, peer pressure can be intense.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To sum up, although young people face many problems and restrictions, such as peer pressure, excessive homework and their parents' prohibitions, they overcome all the barriers and enjoy their life exploiting to the full all the advantages of their age and character. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a long, thin object that you use to write or draw in ink
dictionaryExamples: If you write in  pen, or you won't be able to erase mistakes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have to bring with us a notebook, a pen and a pencil. Key English Test; A2; Greek

sense.def: a punishment for doing something that is against a law or rule
dictionaryExamples: The violation carries a penalty of up to three years in prison.
Currently, ticket holders pay a penalty equal to 25% of the ticket price when they change their flight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although, the government can [i]ncrease the penalties for neglec[t]ful driving. In this regard, police officers are already paying more attention to drunk drivers. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: an advantage given in some sports to a team or player when the opposing team or player breaks a rule
dictionaryExamples: The referee awarded  a penalty kick.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After twenty more minutes of playing or I should say fighting, none of us could score and finally the match had to be decided by penalties. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a long, thin, wooden object with a black or colored point that you write or draw with
dictionaryExamples: a box of colored pencils
pens and pencils
a pencil sharpener
You'd better sharpen that pencil.
Write your comments in the margin of the report in  pencil.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You must bring a pencil with you. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: a large, black-and-white sea bird that swims and cannot fly
dictionaryExamples: A row of penguins stood at the water's edge.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's wonderful, you can see the whales swimming in the sea, the sea [lions] lying on the beach and the penguins. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a coin or unit of money with a value of one hundredth of a dollar
dictionaryExamples: Have you got a penny? The bill comes to $14.01 and I don't have one.
I put all my pennies in a jar and once a year count them and bring them to the bank.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What about those who haven't any money? . . . Sometimes we can give them a few pennies, but most of all we are trying not to see them. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: someone who you write to regularly but have never met
dictionaryExamples: I once had a pen pal in Jamaica.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Teacher: I'd like an Australian pen-pal. I'll write to him twice a week. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a sum of money paid regularly by the government or a private company to a person who has stopped working because they are old or ill
dictionaryExamples: a pension plan
a public pension fund/system
He won't be able to collect  his pension until he's 65.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, you'll have to pay attention to your health, if you don't want to die before [you get] your pension. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: more than one person
dictionaryExamples: Many people never get any exercise.
We've invited thirty people to our party.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like talking to people about music, films and books. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: all the ordinary people in a country
dictionaryExamples: The rebels have gained the support of the people.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: John Paul II is one of the few popes - if not the only one - to have actually been in contact with the people. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: a black, gray, white or red powder produced by crushing a type of dried berry and used to give food a spicy flavor
dictionaryExamples: freshly ground black pepper
salt and pepper
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You put the chicken in the oven, but before [you do that], you put salt and pepper or [a] piece of bacon on top of [the] chicken.

sense.def: a hollow green, red or yellow vegetable that tastes mild or a similar vegetable that tastes hot
dictionaryExamples: green/red/bell peppers
Do you like hot peppers?
chili/jalapeno peppers
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I eat every [kind] of vegetable - carrots, green peppers... Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: for each
dictionaryExamples: The meal will cost $20 per person.
The car was traveling at 70 miles per hour (70 mph).
There are more cafés per square mile here than anywhere else in the country.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's two hours per lesson. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: to think of something or someone in a particular way
dictionaryExamples: The British are often perceived as being very formal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, travel[l]ing with parents or other family members is generally perceived as less exciting and interesting than travel[l]ing with friends. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to notice something that is not easy to notice
dictionaryExamples: We perceived a faint light in the distance.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I could perceive a dim light through the shutters but immediat[e]ly afterwards it disappeared. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: for or out of every 100, shown by the symbol %
dictionaryExamples: You got 20 percent of the answers right - that means one out of every five.
Only 40% of people bothered to vote in the election.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is assumed that 78 percent [of] those who use this restaurant are businessm[en]. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: an amount of something, often expressed as a number out of 100
dictionaryExamples: What percentage of women return to work after having a baby?
Interest rates have risen by two percentage points.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If "today's youngster[s]" [are] asked where [they] would like to have lunch, a high percentage of them will probably answer "McDonalds". First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: what you think or believe about someone or something
dictionaryExamples: The public perception of him as a hero is surprising.
These photographs will affect people's perceptions of war.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Today's royalty is a lot less respected and the media influence of modern times has shaped and transformed much of our perception. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: quick to notice or understand things
dictionaryExamples: a perceptive writer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Both incidents show how perceptive Lucy is. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: without fault, or as good as possible
dictionaryExamples: a perfect day/evening
You have a perfect English accent.
The car is five years old but is in almost perfect condition.
Her performance was perfect.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I bought a mobile phone. It's perfect for me. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: exactly right for someone or something
dictionaryExamples: You'd be perfect for the job.
The weather's just perfect for a picnic.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On one hand, a small school in the countryside is great because it is in a quiet place that is perfect for studying. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used to emphasize a noun
dictionaryExamples: His suggestion makes perfect sense.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When the visit is a grandmother with whom you have nothing to talk about I don't think there is much you can do about it. But if you wake up in the morning and the first thing you see in front of you is the face of a perfect stranger with wrinkles all over the place staring at you with motherly eyes... wh[at] would be your first reaction? Yell, of course! Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: the tense of a verb that shows action that has happened in the past or before another time or event
dictionaryExamples: the present/past perfect
In English, the perfect is formed with a form of the verb "have" and the past participle of the verb - for example, "She has visited Mexico."

sense.def: to make something as good as it can be
dictionaryExamples: I've spent hours perfecting my speech.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Instead, it matters how far they get with perfecting their skills. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Serbian

sense.def: when someone or something is perfect
dictionaryExamples: She strives for perfection in everything she does.
chicken legs cooked to perfection
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, he is hard-working and always strives for perfection. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: in a perfect way
dictionaryExamples: The jacket fits perfectly, the skirt, not so well.
They're perfectly suited.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like wearing skirts made out of denim because they fit me perfectly. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: used to emphasize the word that follows
dictionaryExamples: To be perfectly honest, I don't care any more.
You know perfectly well what the matter is.
I made it perfectly clear to him what I meant.
I was perfectly happy on my own.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I told them I hadn't brought a map because I knew the way perfectly well. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to entertain people by acting, dancing, singing, playing music, etc.
dictionaryExamples: She composes and performs her own music.
A major Hollywood star will be performing on stage tonight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Later a band performs and everybody starts to dance and sing. Preliminary English Test; B1; Basque

sense.def: to do a job or a piece of work
dictionaryExamples: Computers can perform a variety of tasks.
The operation will be performed next week.
Most of the students performed well on the exam.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The technology of computers can [produce] special effects [i]n films and cartoons, it can also be used to perform some kind[s] of surgery. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: acting, dancing, singing, or playing music to entertain people
dictionaryExamples: a performance of Arthur Miller's play, "The Crucible"
She gave a superb performance as Lady Macbeth.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was sure that the legendary instrument that the great player used during his performances had to be very big, as the box is. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: how successful someone or something is
dictionaryExamples: The new suits help swimmers to improve their performance.
High-performance  cars are the most expensive.
This was a very impressive performance by the young player, who scored 12 points within the first 10 minutes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I do some exercises in order to improve my performance in the water. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: someone who entertains people by acting, singing, dancing or playing music
dictionaryExamples: He's a brilliant performer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are going to watch "Bodygu[a]rd", which has so many famous performers. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: a liquid with a pleasant smell, usually made from oils taken from flowers or spices, which is often used on the skin
dictionaryExamples: What perfume are you wearing?
She adores French perfume.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I got nice trouse[r]s, books and perfume. Key English Test; A2; Polish

sense.def: used to show that something is possible or that you are not certain about something
dictionaryExamples: He hasn't written to me recently - perhaps he's lost my address.
We plan to travel to Europe - to Spain or Italy perhaps.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What about Saturday or perhaps Friday? Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: a length of time
dictionaryExamples: Her work means that she spends long periods away from home.
Unemployment in the first half of the year was 2% lower than in the same period last year.
The study will be carried out over a six-month period.
The house was built during the colonial period.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hi Jo, I've seen  a restaurant [is] looking for a waitress during the period from June to August. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: in school, a division of time in the day when a subject is taught
dictionaryExamples: We have six periods of science a week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After the period, when the bell rang, I stayed in the class [to] ask some questions and my new teacher gave me some explanations. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: a mark (.) that is put at the end of a sentence, or at the end of a word that has been shortened
something special in addition to the money you are paid  that you are given because of your job
dictionaryExamples: Free child care for preschool children of employees was a popular perk.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The economy nowadays is so technologically driven it is common belief that having a job in the computer industry means high pay an[d] perks. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: lasting or continuing for a long time or forever
dictionaryExamples: She is looking for a permanent place to stay.
Are you looking for a temporary or a permanent job?
The disease can cause permanent damage to the brain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am a permanent member of [the] Fear factor club. Preliminary English Test; B1; Hindi

sense.def: always and forever
dictionaryExamples: I seem to be permanently broke.
Michael and his family have settled permanently in Brazil.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although I am not permanently employed, I found it very interesting to help skilled instructors teach other people to swim and surf. First Certificate in English; B2; Serbian

sense.def: when you allow someone to do something
dictionaryExamples: She gave him permission immediately.
They even have to ask for permission before they go to the rest room.
The authorities have refused permission for the march to take place.
The zoning board has refused to grant permission to build until the plan is revised to include adequate parking.
