sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My parents didn't give me permission to go but I really wanted to. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to allow something
dictionaryExamples: Photography is not permitted inside the museum.
The prison authorities permit visiting only once a month.
The security system will not permit you to enter without the correct password.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My parents permitted me to go! Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to make something possible
dictionaryExamples: The game starts at 3 pm, weather permitting.
We could stop in to see Ryan on the way home, if time permits.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It offers barbecue (hot meal), disco, and most students agreed (80 percent), and a swimming pool which can be enjoyed by everyone as long as the weather permits. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: an official document that allows you to do something
dictionaryExamples: a work permit
You need a permit to park your car here.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am able to start as soon as possible and due to my grandfather [being] Italian also have d[ual] na[t]ionality, which means that I don't even need [a] work permit. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: continued effort and determination
dictionaryExamples: Hard work and perseverance do pay off in the end.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Would we be still living as our ancestors used to live if people like Einstein, Volta, Newton and Galileo [had not] had the perseverance and intelligence that allowed them to discover things such as the theory of relativity? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: If an unpleasant feeling or situation persists, it continues to exist.
dictionaryExamples: If symptoms persist, consult a doctor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my opinion her achievement is based on the fact that she did manage to alter the image of a handicapped person which persisted in many minds. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to continue to do something although it is annoying other people
dictionaryExamples: He persists in calling me Jane, even though I've corrected him twice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Most surprising perhaps is the fact that although many people are aware of the shortage of drinkable water, [they] persist in either leaving the tap run[ning] or just consume water when it is unnecessary, something that in my opinion is inexcusable. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: when someone or something persists
dictionaryExamples: He has been campaigning for better highway safety for years - you have to admire his persistence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A reward for months of effort and persistence had at last arrived. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: continuing to do something in a determined way
dictionaryExamples: He can be very persistent when he wants something.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I learned how to make the most out of failure, how to be persistent in my efforts and strive for excellence. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Bulgarian

sense.def: a human being
dictionaryExamples: He's a very dangerous person.
You're the only person I know at this party.
Who was the first person to swim the English Channel?
Dinner cost about $35 per person.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She's [a] very good person. I really like my friends. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: If you do something in person, you go somewhere to do it yourself.
dictionaryExamples: You have to pick up the document in person.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am looking forward [to] meeting you in person. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: relating to or belonging to a particular person
dictionaryExamples: I can only speak from my personal experience.
This is a personal opinion/view and not that of the government.
Remember to  take all your personal belongings with you as you leave the plane.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The only personal belongings he took was a black leather suitcase. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: designed for or used by one person
dictionaryExamples: a personal computer
a personal loan
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The activity that I like best is to surf the Web with a powerful personal computer. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: relating to the private parts of someone's life, including their relationships or feelings
dictionaryExamples: He has a few personal problems at the moment.
Do you mind if I ask you a personal question?
His resignation was apparently for personal rather than professional reasons.
We know very little about his personal life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I wanted to see him and talk to him about some personal problems. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: how clean a person's body, teeth, hair, etc. are
dictionaryExamples:
Her 
                         personal hygiene
                      is not as good as it should be.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The ones that need medical services at home have hardly had anyone, and no one has helped them with personal hygiene. Certificate in Advanced English; [no level]; [no L1 data]

sense.def: the type of person you are, which is shown by the way you behave, feel and think
dictionaryExamples: She has a very warm personality.
He is well qualified for the job, but he does lack personality.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I mean, when she dances, she transmits strength and a big personality. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a famous person
dictionaryExamples: The show is hosted by a popular TV personality.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What is more, you could take part in the festival without paying for it and meet some famous personalities from the world of music. First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: used when you give your opinion
dictionaryExamples: Personally, I think the show is going to be a great success.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Personally, I really like green spag[h]etti. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: done by or affecting one person and not someone else
dictionaryExamples: These figures should be correct because I've checked them personally.
He believes that parents should be made personally responsible for their children's behavior.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At the end of the concert, when it was after midnight and everyone had already left, the group came up to each of us (who helped out) and thanked us personally! First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to think that someone is criticizing you or to feel that a failure or bad situation is your fault
dictionaryExamples: You shouldn't take everything so personally.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She tends to take things too personally, and sometimes she over[r]eacts. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: the people who work for an organization
dictionaryExamples: military personnel
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We also employ 10000 workers in 10 factories across the country and additional administrative personnel. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: the way you think about something
dictionaryExamples: Being unemployed has made me see things from a different perspective.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have performed a class survey and interviewed Fordham residents, who see this issue from a different perspective. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: when things are in perspective, you think about them in a sensible and  realistic way, and understand how important or unimportant they really are
dictionaryExamples: You must keep things in perspective - the overall situation isn't really that bad.
When you see pictures of their suffering, it puts your own problems in perspective.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it will enable me to see things more in perspective. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to make someone agree to do something by talking to them a lot about it
dictionaryExamples: If she doesn't want to go, nothing you can say will persuade her.
I persuaded her (that) it was the right thing to do.
He is trying to persuade local and foreign businesses to invest in the project.
Using a bunch of bananas, the zoo-keeper persuaded the monkey back into its cage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had to persuade them to let me go and make enquiries. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: to make someone believe that something is true
dictionaryExamples: Their argument failed to persuade me.
It's no use trying to persuade him (that) you're innocent.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My friends persuaded me that everythin[g] was going well. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: when you persuade someone
dictionaryExamples: I'm sure she'll agree, she just needs a little gentle persuasion.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After a lot of persuasion I decided to take part in the Public Speaking. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: able to make people agree to do something
dictionaryExamples: It's a very persuasive argument.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The presentation and the enthusiasm of the representatives was very persuasive and appealing. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: always believing that bad things are likely to happen
dictionaryExamples: The tone of the meeting was very pessimistic.
The doctors are pessimistic  about his chances of recovery.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In his book, [the] most important thing is his character. He has never been pessimistic, he has never hated his parents. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: an animal that someone keeps in their home
dictionaryExamples: They have several pets - a dog, two cats and a guinea pig.
my pet rabbit
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like this place because I have lots of friends [there]. The people, houses, pets - [everything] is very good. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: extremely frightened
dictionaryExamples: I'm petrified of spiders.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was petrified as well as confused. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: unimportant or not serious
dictionaryExamples: petty details/concerns
petty crime/theft
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Focusing on others makes us forget about our petty problems. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: someone who is trained to prepare or sell medicines
dictionaryExamples: The pharmacist gave me some medicine.

sense.def: a store or part of a store that prepares and sells medicines
dictionaryExamples: I need to leave my prescription at the pharmacy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sometimes such a situation could happen when you need some food or something [from the] pharmacy. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a stage or period which is part of a longer period
dictionaryExamples: The first phase of the project is likely to be completed by August.
We're entering a new phase in international relations.
When I was in my early teens I went through a phase of only wearing black.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many people disagree about the best phase of a man's life but I defin[i]tely believe that [the] teenage years are the most beautiful of your life and I have many reasons for believing that! First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: extremely successful or showing great qualities or abilities
dictionaryExamples: The movie has been a phenomenal success.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now grown-up and minus a few dreams, the soaps give us the opportunity to dream but still connect to the stars since although the all look phenomenal they have their insecurities and flaws. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: something that exists or happens, usually something unusual
dictionaryExamples: storms, lightning, and other natural phenomena
Road rage seems to be a fairly recent phenomenon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: An unexpected phenomenon that someone called "drunkenness tourism" has appeared in the Mediter[r]anean villages and towns. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan

sense.def: someone who studies or writes about the meaning of life
dictionaryExamples: Plato was a Greek philosopher.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He wasn't a teacher, he wasn't a philosopher, but he was a great artist. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: relating to the study or writing of philosophy
dictionaryExamples: a philosophical problem/question
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Ralph started taking advice from Piggy and asking him philosophical questions. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: accepting unpleasant situations in a calm and wise way
dictionaryExamples: She seems fairly philosophical about failing her exam.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One of the traits that attrac[t]s me most in the Balinese is their philosophical attitude towards life and their strong belief in Hindu gods and spirits. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: the study or writing of ideas about the meaning of life, or a particular set of ideas about the meaning of life
dictionaryExamples: Descartes is considered by many to be the father of modern philosophy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have been enthu[si]astic students of history, literature and philosophy for three years now. First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: a way of thinking about what should be done in life
dictionaryExamples: My philosophy has always been to give those with ability the chance to progress.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Brighton college has changed its philosophy considerably over the past decades. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: a piece of electronic equipment that you use  to talk to someone who is in another place
dictionaryExamples: Just then, his phone rang.
Could you answer the phone?
We talk on the phone about twice a week.
She's on the phone, but can see you in just a minute.
You had three phone calls this morning.
Will you excuse me? I've got to make a phone call.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want [to] buy a new phone for my brother because I broke his in an accident. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: a picture produced using a camera
dictionaryExamples: She took a lot of photos of the kids.
vacation/wedding photos
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sometimes I take photos [of] them and I feed these bird[s]. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: a copy of a document made with a machine which produces copies of documents using light and electricity
dictionaryExamples: I made photocopies of my résumé and sent them to several companies.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As far as my level of English is concerned, I have obtained my Cambridge Examination and I enclose a photocopy of the certificate. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a picture produced using a camera
dictionaryExamples: a color/black-and-white photograph
My parents took a lot of photographs of us when we were small.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also want to take photographs of beautiful views. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: to take a picture using a camera
dictionaryExamples: I prefer photographing people rather than places.
MacKay was photographed leaving the building.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This city is not big as you know, so we don't have m[any] interesting buildings to be photographed. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: someone who takes photographs, especially someone whose job is to  do this
dictionaryExamples: a fashion photographer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yesterday, my new boyfriend gave me a camera. I [really] liked it because I [want to] be a photographer one day. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: the activity or job of taking photographs
dictionaryExamples: She's taking an evening class in photography.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm writing to you because I decided to [take] a photography course. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: a phrase that consists of a verb in combination with a preposition or adverb or both, which has a different meaning from the meaning of its separate parts
dictionaryExamples: "Look after," "work out," and "make up for" are all phrasal verbs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then we studied some phrasal verbs and I was supposed to read a text about feelings and relationships. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a group of words that are used together, and which often have a particular meaning
dictionaryExamples: Here are some phrases that may be useful in your essays.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [A] man dressed in black would ask me: "How many apples are there in the bedroom?" [and] I should answer with a scratch [o]n the nose and the phrase: "Three and seven quarters sir." Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: related to the body
dictionaryExamples: physical activity/fitness/exercise/strength/disabilities
physical appearance
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Riding your bicycle is the best kind of physical activity. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: relating to real things that you can see and touch
dictionaryExamples: a physical object
There was no physical evidence linking Jones to Shaw's murder.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In other words, books as physical objects represent memories of specific times of my life and occasionally I enjoy recalling them by reading (again) some passages of already read books. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: in a way that relates to the body or someone's appearance
dictionaryExamples: physically active/fit
Physically I find him very attractive.
The work is physically demanding.
Special holidays are available for physically disabled people.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Most people believe that team sport[s] help children to become healthier, both mentally and physically, but there are those who have objections to this statement. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: the scientific study of matter and energy and the effect that they have on each other
dictionaryExamples: nuclear physics
a physics lab
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can't miss that class because it's a physics class and it's essential for me to go, because I think I can't study physics by myself. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: a large musical instrument with a row of black and white keys which are pressed to play notes
dictionaryExamples: We're buying a new piano.
I play the piano.
We all joined in the song, with Pat at the piano/on piano.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My hobby is playing the piano. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to choose something or someone
dictionaryExamples: Pick a card from the box to send to your sister.
She was picked for the Olympic team.
She was picked to play for the team.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can go to the park and play tennis and golf. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Hungarian

sense.def: to make music with a musical instrument
dictionaryExamples: He plays the piano.

sense.def: to make a radio, CD, etc. produce sounds

sense.def: to be one of the people or things that are involved in an event or situation
dictionaryExamples: Alcohol plays a part in around 60% of violent crime.

sense.def: to play a piece of music by remembering the notes
dictionaryExamples: She plays all the songs by ear.

sense.def: to decide how to deal with a situation as it develops
dictionaryExamples: I'm not sure what to tell Dad - I'll just have to play it by ear.

sense.def: to not deal with a situation seriously or honestly

sense.def: a story that is written for actors to perform, usually in a theater
dictionaryExamples: We saw a play on Broadway.

sense.def: when children enjoy themselves with toys and games
dictionaryExamples: a play area

sense.def: behavior that is fair, honest, and does not take advantage of people
dictionaryExamples: The public needs to feel a sense of fair play from the government.

sense.def: someone who takes part in a game or sport
dictionaryExamples: a football/tennis player

sense.def: someone who plays a musical instrument
dictionaryExamples: a piano/violin player
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I g[o]t a spe[c]tacular guitar signed by Adrian Smith, Iron Maiden's guitar player. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: something that produces sound or video
dictionaryExamples: a CD/DVD/MP3 player
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yesterday I left my mp3 player in your house. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: an area designed for children to play in outside, especially at a school
dictionaryExamples: We always play football in the playground.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I lost it in the playground. Key English Test; A2; German

sense.def: a strong request
dictionaryExamples: an emotional plea for forgiveness
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "I promise, I'll never ever do it again" she nodded her head to emphasi[z]e the seriousness of her plea. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to say in a court of law if you are guilty or not guilty of the crime you have been accused of
dictionaryExamples: He pleaded not guilty to five felony charges.

dictionaryExamples: He pleaded with her to come back.

dictionaryExamples: You'll just have to plead ignorance.

sense.def: enjoyable, attractive, friendly, or easy to like

sense.def: in a pleasant way

sense.def: used to make a request more polite

sense.def: to make someone feel happy

sense.def: used to say that someone can have or do anything they want
dictionaryExamples: Feel free to talk about anything you please.

sense.def: happy or satisfied
dictionaryExamples: Are you pleased about John's promotion?

sense.def: a polite way of greeting someone when you meet them for the first time
dictionaryExamples: I'm very pleased to meet you at last!

sense.def: enjoyable
dictionaryExamples: a pleasurable experience

Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: a feeling of happiness or enjoyment

dictionaryExamples: It was such a pleasure to meet you.

sense.def: (the state of having) enough or more than enough, or a large amount
dictionaryExamples: "Would you like some more coffee?" "No thanks, I've had plenty."

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She's going to stay 3 weeks so we'll have plenty of time to talk about our life, dreams, etc. Preliminary English Test; B1; Hungarian

sense.def: an unpleasant or difficult situation
dictionaryExamples: the plight of the sick and the poor
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My brother's plight has always been a concern of mine. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

dictionaryExamples: The movie has a very simple plot.

sense.def: a piece of land, often for growing food or for building on

sense.def: a secret plan to do something that is wrong, harmful, or illegal

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We had to check eve[r]y plug, switch, lights. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: something you put in a hole to block it

sense.def: to connect a piece of electrical equipment to an electricity supply or to another piece of equipment

dictionaryExamples:
I shouldn't have to pay for travel out of my own 
                         pocket.

sense.def: relating to poetry
dictionaryExamples: poetic language

I know I may miss many important points but I promise you [I will] get the best mark (result) in the next exam. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: the thin, sharp end of something

sense.def: one of the marks on a compass

blocks.phrase: be at/on the point of doing sth

sense.def: to be going to do something very soon

blocks.phrase: make a point of doing sth

sense.def: to be certain that you always do a particular thing
dictionaryExamples: He made a point of learning all the names of his staff.

sense.def: a quality or ability which someone has
dictionaryExamples: I know she's bossy but she has lots of good points.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "I wonder why Mr Co put up with her?" Ku mumbled. "But I suppose she had her good points." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: one of the marks on a compass
dictionaryExamples: the points of the compass

sense.def: not important or not connected with what you are talking about

dictionaryExamples: His report was short and to the point.

sense.def: a subject that causes disagreement or makes people angry when it is discussed
dictionaryExamples: Money is a sore point with him at the moment.

sense.def: If something points in a particular direction, it is turned toward that direction.
dictionaryExamples: The street sign points left.

blocks.phrasalVerb: point out sth or point sth out

sense.def: to tell someone about some information, often because they do not know it or have forgotten it

dictionaryExamples: pointless arguments/conflict

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, people who meet through e-mails and chatrooms can confirm that talking or sending messages to someone you can't see is pointless and boring. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: an opinion

You have to be willing to see other people's points of view.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That is my point of view. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a way of thinking about a situation
dictionaryExamples: From the point of view of personal savings, the cut in interest rates is bad news.

sense.def: very harmful and able to cause illness or death
dictionaryExamples: poisonous chemicals

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, the people in the future will probably wear clothes to protect themselves from the polluted air and water, the harmful ultra-violet rays from the sun and all the dangerous and poisonous gases or chemicals which [are the] result of a developed country. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: A poisonous animal uses poison in order to defend itself.
dictionaryExamples: a poisonous snake
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some of the animals, like poisonous snakes, crocodiles, [and] lions, are kept in special cages. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a large, white bear that lives in areas near the North Pole
dictionaryExamples: Polar bears can be very dangerous.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So it's very difficult to create real-life conditions for some animals, for instance for polar bears and eagles. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a long, thin stick made of wood or metal, often used to hold something up
dictionaryExamples: tent poles
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It showed two young women in t-shirts and shorts leaning against a big pole stating '90 miles to Cuba'. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to be complete opposites
dictionaryExamples: They are poles apart in their attitudes to religion.

dictionaryExamples: I think you should call the police.
The police are investigating  him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were dancing [and] then [the] police arrived, because of [the] loud music. Key English Test; A2; Polish

sense.def: a man who is a member of the police
dictionaryExamples: His dad is a policeman.

sense.def: a male or female member of the police
dictionaryExamples: There were several police officers at the scene.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then, I saw a police officer [on] the corner of the street. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: the office of the police in a town or part of a city
dictionaryExamples: We went to the police station to report the theft.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My home is opposite the police station. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: a woman who is a member of the police

dictionaryExamples: They believe that the European Community needs a common foreign and security policy.

sense.def: in a polite way
dictionaryExamples: He thanked them politely.

sense.def: the state of being polite
dictionaryExamples: We were impressed by their politeness.

sense.def: relating to politics
dictionaryExamples: political leaders/parties

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm very interested in Italian political life, and I want to get news [all the] time. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: in a way that is connected with politics
dictionaryExamples: Politically, she is very experienced.
a politically active group
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays most women have equal chances of education, are permitted to work, sign any bur[eau]cratic papers with no need of their husbands' countersign[ature], are politically active and have an important professional career. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: someone who works in politics, especially a member of the government
dictionaryExamples: Churchill was a distinguished politician.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was now the third month [since] the gangster had kidnapped her, because of her being the daughter of an important politician. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: ideas and activities relating to how a country or area is governed
dictionaryExamples: He has little interest in local politics.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a com[e]dy program. They usually make jokes about politics or football players. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to make water, air, soil, etc. dirty or harmful
dictionaryExamples: We need a fuel that won't pollute the environment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Most of them don't pollute the environment, and they don't create traffic jams on the roads. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: damage caused to water, air, etc. by harmful substances or waste
dictionaryExamples: air/water pollution

The manifesto includes tough measures to tackle road congestion and environmental pollution.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is less pollution than in the city and [it] is qui[e]ter too. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: an area of water smaller than a lake, often artificially made
dictionaryExamples: a duck pond
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After that, we'll visit "Suizenji-Park" which is a real Japanese Garden with a pond and many kinds of flowers and trees. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to think carefully about something
dictionaryExamples: He pondered what might have happened if he hadn't gone home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, I am still pondering and I am still not quite sure of what it means and so I asked myself, would climbing a mountain be a challenge for me? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a small horse
dictionaryExamples: I have a pony.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The forest is inhabited by wild bears, wild ponies, golden eagles and non-poisonous snakes. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: an area of water that has been made for people to swim in
dictionaryExamples: The hotel has two outdoor pools.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Come with short[s] that can [get] wet because after we paint my bedroom, we'll go to my pool. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: a game in which two people use long, thin sticks to hit colored balls into holes around the edge of a table
dictionaryExamples: We played pool all evening.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had a pool table in my bedroom and I had a lot of videogames. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a small area of water or a small amount of liquid on a surface
dictionaryExamples: We dipped our feet in a shallow pool by the rocks.
a pool of blood
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I came into the kitchen, I saw a pool of blood [o]n the floor. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: having very little money or few possessions
dictionaryExamples: Most of these people are very poor.
Many medicines are too expensive for poorer countries to afford.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It cost 500 Euro [so] it isn't for poor people. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: used to show sympathy for someone
dictionaryExamples: The poor girl didn't have any friends.
That cold sounds terrible - poor you!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was about one poor boy who lost his parents [at a] really young age. Key English Test; A2; Russian

sense.def: of very low quality
dictionaryExamples: poor health

a poor harvest
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But the quality of [the] food was poor. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: not having much skill at a particular activity
dictionaryExamples: Her spelling has always been poor.
Sam's a poor swimmer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since I was a teenager, I've often drawn and painted but without any kind of teaching, so my tec[h]nique is poor. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: If something is poor in a particular substance, it has very little of the substance.
dictionaryExamples: Avoid foods which are high in calories but poor in nutrients.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They couldn't avoid a diet poor in vitamins, because of the shortage of food. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: people who are poor
dictionaryExamples: She spent her life working with the poor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is widely believed that under his management, Greece advanced economically and socially, made steps forward concerning the relationships with other countries and people, (especially the poor) loved him, for he made them feel important. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: badly
dictionaryExamples: poorly educated
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the contrary, to my mind both issues were handled rather poorly. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: modern music with a strong beat that is popular with the general public, especially with young people
dictionaryExamples: pop music
a pop concert/song
What do you want to listen to - jazz, classical or pop?
She wants to be a pop singer/star like Madonna.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like pop music. Key English Test; A2; Catalan

sense.def: to make a short sound like a small explosion, or to make something do this by breaking it
dictionaryExamples: The music played and champagne corks popped.
He popped the balloon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Never had she experienced anything like it before, and all her intensity came back in one big bang, just as if she had been a bottle of champagne that someone had been shaking all these years, and now it had finally popped and the joy of living was pouring out of it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: seeds of corn that have been heated to break open into soft, light balls and are eaten as a snack, often with salt and butter
dictionaryExamples: Which would you like, popcorn or potato chips?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So we have time to buy popcorn & soda until the film starts at 8:00. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: liked by many people
dictionaryExamples: She's the most popular teacher in the school.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The video is very popular. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: for or involving ordinary people rather than specialists or very educated people
dictionaryExamples: popular entertainment/culture
He enjoys enormous popular support.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Due to his studies in Persian folklore and popular culture, he is the progenitor of anthropology in Iran. First Certificate in English; B2; Farsi

dictionaryExamples: The allegations are false, contrary to popular belief.

sense.def: the quality of being liked by many people
dictionaryExamples: the increasing popularity of organic food
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We agreed that something had to be done to promote the popularity of local films. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: the number of people living in a particular area
dictionaryExamples: a growing/shrinking population
What's the population of Brazil?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With a population [of] about 800 people, that town really surprised me! Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: all the people living in a particular area, or all the people or animals of a particular type
dictionaryExamples: a 9% rise in the prison population

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Their yellow and black stripe has a mysterious beauty (which is the main reason for the hug[e] decrease [in the] tiger population). First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: meat from a pig
dictionaryExamples: a pork chop
pork sausages
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We ordered pork chops, boiled potatoes, [and] greens.Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: a town by the sea or by a river that has a harbor, or the harbor itself
dictionaryExamples: a fishing/container port
the Belgian port of Zeebrugge
We had a good view of all the ships coming into/leaving port.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The name is very interesting because the hotel is near the port. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: able to be carried
dictionaryExamples: a portable computer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Laptops are indeed a portable office. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: the amount of food served to one person, especially in a restaurant
dictionaryExamples: The portions are very generous in this restaurant.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think you should take [a] packed lunch with you, because the restaurant is far too expensive and the portions are too small. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a part or share of something larger
dictionaryExamples: A large/major portion of the company's profit goes straight back into new projects.
I accept my portion of the blame.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Such an event will probably attract publicity (TV, radio, newspapers) and since we are a new company, we will have the opportunity to become know[n] to a large portion of the population in a short amount of time. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a painting, drawing, or photograph of someone
dictionaryExamples: a portrait painter
She's commissioned an artist to paint her portrait/paint a portrait of her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Downstairs we can find pictures [by] old masters and a great portrait of the Spanish King Charles the Third. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: If a book or movie portrays someone or something, it describes or shows them.
dictionaryExamples: Both novels portray the lives of professional athletes.
In the movie he's portrayed as a hero.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As soon as Piggy appears in the novel he is portrayed as an outsider. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: the way that someone or something is portrayed
dictionaryExamples: He won several awards for his portrayal of the great artist.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: While this film may be criticised on grounds that it is a Swiss director looking at his own country, Minger's view proves to give an overly critical portrayal of Switzerland, showing that hindsight is indeed possible, even in such a small country. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: the situation that someone is in
dictionaryExamples: When two of your best friends argue it puts you in a bad position.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She knows the person that owns the club, who decided to organize a private party for her 18th birthday. I wish [I was] in her position. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: the place where something or someone is, often in relation to other things
dictionaryExamples: I found our position on the map.
You've moved the furniture around - the sofa is in a different position.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like [this restaurant] because of [its] position, the old town, and most of all because the owner is a friend of mine so that the bill is not too expensive for me! Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: the way someone is sitting, standing, or lying, or if something is pointing up or down, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a kneeling position

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Four hundred kms in that [un]comfortable position was terrible for us. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: the part that someone plays in a game such as football
dictionaryExamples: I didn't know you played hockey - what position  do you play?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a basketball club and all those guys in the club are much bigger than me. At first we talked to each other [about] which position we had to play. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Perhaps the style of their dress will indicate their position in society too. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a job in a company, school, or other organization
dictionaryExamples: He held the position for six years.
She applied for a position in the same company I work for.
We were able to fill both of the new teaching positions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Mr. Greenfield I am writing in response to the advertisement which I saw published in my local newspaper, as I would like to apply for the position you offer. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

blocks.phrase: be in a position to do sth

sense.def: to be able to do something because of your situation
dictionaryExamples: I'm not in a position to talk about this at the moment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But no one is in a position to know about it yet, since now it is just an option. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: If someone or something is in position, they are in the place that they should be in.
dictionaryExamples: The police were all in position.

blocks.phrase: put sb in a difficult position

sense.def: to cause someone to be in a difficult situation
dictionaryExamples: When two of your best friends argue it puts you in a very difficult position.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know that I will put you in a difficult position with my absence but I must leave. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: feeling enthusiastic and  happy about your life and your future
dictionaryExamples: a positive attitude
I'm feeling much more positive about things now.
We showed people samples of the product and got a very positive reaction/response.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is lovely and she [is] always positive. Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan

sense.def: A positive effect is good and makes something better.
dictionaryExamples: The improved diet had a positive effect on his mood.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All the colors and the smell of fresh and dried flowers has such a positive effect on me that life feels great. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: expressing the answer yes
dictionaryExamples: We received a positive answer/reply to our request for a meeting.

sense.def: certain that something is true
dictionaryExamples: "Are you sure you saw him?" "Absolutely positive."

sense.def: to have or own something

sense.def: when you have or own something
dictionaryExamples: I have in my possession a photograph which may be of interest to you.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After many hours of deliberation, the decision was taken to search every hut and if anyone was found in possession of the diary then they would be killed for having commited an act of theft. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: in grammar, a possessive word or form of a word shows who or what something belongs to

sense.def: wanting someone to love and spend time with you and no one else

sense.def: as much/quickly/soon, etc. as something can happen or be done

sense.def: every time it is possible
dictionaryExamples: I try to use olive oil whenever possible.

sense.def: every time it is possible
dictionaryExamples: Wherever possible I use honey instead of sugar.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They have to implement more economical and eco-friendly means of transport like electric trains instead of diesel ones and trying to operate alternatives like trams instead of b[u]ses wherever possible and more eco-friendly buses where not. International English Language Testing System; B2; Marathi

sense.def: the best/cheapest/worst, etc. that can happen or exist
dictionaryExamples: We need to complete the work in the shortest possible time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But I strongly believe that with good will and enough effort from both sides - our club members and you - we will work everything out in the best possible way! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: used when something is not certain
dictionaryExamples: Someone, possibly Tom, left the window open.

sense.def: used in polite questions
dictionaryExamples: Could I possibly borrow your computer?

sense.def: used with "can" or "could" for emphasis

sense.def: to leave a message on a Web site
dictionaryExamples: I posted a query about a Chilean novelist.

sense.def: to make certain that someone always knows what is happening
dictionaryExamples: Keep me posted on anything that happens while I'm away.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We will keep our members posted on the best eating places in town. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to be sent to France/London/Singapore, etc. to work, usually for the government or the military
dictionaryExamples: He was posted to Germany for two years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At the age of eleven, my father was posted to Montreal and, naturally, I had to go along. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: relating to the system of sending letters and packages
dictionaryExamples: the postal service/system
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's just another strike that has affected our everyday life, and Polish postal services in particular. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: a card, often with a photograph or picture on one side, that can be sent in the mail without an envelope
dictionaryExamples: Ella sent me a postcard from Japan.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thanks for your postcard. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: a large, printed picture or notice that you put on a wall, in order to decorate a place or to advertise something
dictionaryExamples: The children put up posters on the classroom walls.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can give you some posters for the concert. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a place where stamps are sold and from which letters and packages are sent
dictionaryExamples: Where's the nearest post office?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The house is behind the post office. Key English Test; A2; Swiss German

sense.def: to arrange for something to happen at a later time
dictionaryExamples: They decided to postpone their trip to Mexico until next year.
We had to postpone visiting my sister because our children were sick.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm doing an experiment tomorrow which I can't postpone. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: the position of your back, shoulders, etc. when you are standing or sitting
dictionaryExamples: She has very good/bad/poor posture.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As for the furniture, replacing old rickety chairs would result in better working conditions and prevent fatigue, stress, incapa[c]ity for work due to bad posture, therefore speeding up productivity and doing away with complaints about pain and poor health. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: a round container, usually used for storing things or for cooking
dictionaryExamples: a flower pot
There's plenty of space in the kitchen for all your pots and pans.
Fill a large pot with water and bring it to a boil.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: By the right window there is [a] green plant in [a] pot. Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: a round vegetable with a brown, yellow, or red skin that grows in the ground
dictionaryExamples: boiled/baked/roasted potatoes
mashed potato/potatoes
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like to eat mashed potatoes with chicken and salad. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: a very thin slice of potato that has been cooked in oil and is eaten cold
dictionaryExamples: a bag of potato chips
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After the film we can go to my house and have potato chips which you like the most. Key English Test; A2; Hindi

sense.def: possible when the necessary conditions exist
dictionaryExamples: A number of potential buyers have expressed interest in the company.

The accident is a reminder of the potential dangers involved in oil production.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a potential customer, I need some further information. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: someone's or something's ability to develop, achieve or succeed
dictionaryExamples: The region has enormous potential for economic development.

I think this room has got a lot of potential.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The sheer potential for communication it offers is overwhelming. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: possibly
dictionaryExamples: Hepatitis is a potentially fatal disease.
This crisis is potentially the most serious in the organization's history.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Scientific experiments tend to show that microwaves produced by phones may cause cancers and tumors. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: plates, bowls, etc. that are made from clay
dictionaryExamples: They sell pottery and other handmade goods.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can see very precious pottery and take pictures [of] old goods in antique shop[s]. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: the activity or skill of making plates, bowls, etc. from clay
dictionaryExamples: I am taking a pottery class on Thursday evenings.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So I suggest we should print new ones with the latest information, for example about our new pottery courses. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a unit for measuring weight
dictionaryExamples: One pound is approximately equal to 454 grams.
One kilogram is roughly the same as 2.2 lbs.
There are 16 ounces in one pound.
Ann's baby weighed eight and a half pounds at birth.

sense.def: to hit or beat repeatedly with a lot of force, or to crush something by hitting it repeatedly
dictionaryExamples: I could feel my heart pounding as I went on stage to receive the prize.
The city was pounded to rubble during the war.
He pounded on the door demanding to be let in.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Tina's heart began to pound when suddenly, she heard her name being called out loud! First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to make a liquid flow from or into a container
dictionaryExamples: I poured the milk into the glasses.
Can I pour you a cup of coffee?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The look on his face stopped me cold, as if someone had just poured a freezing bucket [of water] down my back. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: to rain a lot
dictionaryExamples: We can't go out in this weather - it's pouring!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I real[l]y enjoy shopping, special[l]y in winter time whe[n] the rain is pouring down.  Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: to flow quickly and in large amounts
dictionaryExamples: Blood was pouring from my leg.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He woke up and cleaned off the blood that poured from his injured eyebrow. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to enter or leave a place in large numbers
dictionaryExamples: The crowd poured out into the street.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Those are the tourists, wh[o] pour out of the jumbo jet, wh[o] get gathered by a charming guide and wh[o] are driven to the next airconditioned luxury hotel. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

blocks.phrasalVerb: pour sth out or pour out sth

sense.def: If you pour out your feelings or thoughts, you talk very honestly about what is making you sad.
dictionaryExamples: She listened quietly while he poured out his troubles.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She let me pour out my feelings, a thing I did not do to anyone. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: the condition of being extremely poor
dictionaryExamples: Two million people in the city live in  poverty.
He emigrated to Australia to escape the  poverty of his birthplace.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, I think that our grandparents lived in poverty without amen[i]ties. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a dry substance made of many small, loose grains
dictionaryExamples: curry/chilli powder
A packet of white powder was found and police scientists are analyzing it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Have you ever been in a place where the blue sky meets clear waters and [it] has a very fine sand that feels [like] powder? First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: energy, usually electricity, that is used to provide light, heat, etc.
dictionaryExamples: power lines
nuclear/wind/solar power
