sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From my parents, I found out that there was a power failure. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: control or influence over people and events
dictionaryExamples: I don't have any power over him - he does what he wants to.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People can't be trusted [with] power. [T]hey will always reach for more. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: political control in a country
dictionaryExamples: They have been in power too long.
When did this government come to power?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It happened in the November of 1973 and it is the University students' rebellion against the outlaw military goverment which had come to power in 1967 after a violent c[oup]. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

blocks.phrase: do everything in your power to do sth

sense.def: to do everything that you are able and allowed to do
dictionaryExamples: I've done everything in my power to help him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think of myself as an open-minded and cheerful person and if I get the job I will do everything in my power to make sure your visitors will have a great time at the theme park. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: a country that has a lot of influence over others
dictionaryExamples: a major world power
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unfortunately this trend continues into adulthood and has become so bad that in a world power like the United States, one in every three people are considered clinically obese. International English Language Testing System; C1; Afrikaans

sense.def: strength or force
dictionaryExamples: economic/military power
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have enough population and economic power to set up a complete city. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: A powerful person is able to control and influence people and events.
dictionaryExamples: a powerful man/woman
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The man worked for a really powerful man, doing the 'dirty work', but, deep inside [he] was a really good person with a sad childhood. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: having a lot of strength or force
dictionaryExamples: a powerful computer/engine/weapon
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The activity that I like best is surf[ing] the Web with a powerful personal computer. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: having a strong effect on people
dictionaryExamples: a powerful effect/influence
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The importance of this invention is that the information transmitted on it reaches a lot of people at the same time, so it's a very powerful [method] of co[m]munication in our society. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: in a powerful way
dictionaryExamples: She kicked the ball so powerfully that it flew over the fence.
Klaus is a very powerfully-built man.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mary moved to her aunt's house, an inn, but she had got married to a strange, powerfully-built man. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: relating to experience, real situations or actions rather than ideas or imagination
dictionaryExamples: Education is important but practical experience is always an advantage.
The service offers young people practical advice on finding a job.
What's the use of theoretical knowledge that has no practical application?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Before making up my mind, I would like to gain some experience through practical activities. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: able to be done successfully
dictionaryExamples: a practical solution
The plan is simply not practical.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is not a very practical solution for the employees. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: suitable or useful for a situation which may involve some difficulty
dictionaryExamples: practical clothes/shoes
Pale carpets just aren't practical if you have kids.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Instead of being practical, our clothes need to be extravagant. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: Someone who is practical is good at planning things, making sensible decisions, and dealing with problems.
dictionaryExamples: She has a lot of interesting ideas but she's not very practical.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But Macon is a practical man, so he tries to find the advantages [of] living on his own. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: almost or very nearly
dictionaryExamples: She blamed me for practically every mistake in the report.
These changes would cost us practically nothing.
It's practically impossible for me to get home in less than an hour.
They used to argue all the time and now they've practically stopped talking to each other.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Today it is used [in] practically all spheres and its influence on people is not unnotic[e]able. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: when you repeat an activity to improve your ability
dictionaryExamples: We need more practice before the concert.
Are you coming to softball practice after work?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The new class art is on Thursday evening, after basketball practice. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to not do something well because you have not done it recently
dictionaryExamples: I didn't play well today - I'm out of practice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think playing in the club will be a great opportunity for me so as not to be out of practice. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: in a real situation
dictionaryExamples: In practice, the new regulations had little effect.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When you leave school, you have knowledge but you do not know how to use it in practice. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to do something in reality that has been planned or talked about
dictionaryExamples: Next month we will have a chance to put these ideas into practice.
How do you intend to put these proposals into practice?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The doctors cannot really put all their skills into practice. Skills for Life (Level 2); C1; Italian

sense.def: what people do or how they do it
dictionaryExamples: the illegal practice of copying CDs
What can European companies learn from Japanese business practices?
It is common  practice to bury waste in landfills.
What is standard practice  in a situation like this?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Chancellors as well as men in the king's court were known to be corrupt and dishonest, who made bribery a common practice. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to do or play something regularly or repeatedly in order to become skilled at it
dictionaryExamples: She practices the violin every day.
I'm pretty good at tennis, but I need to practice my serve.
His written French is very good but he needs more practice speaking.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like to practice my lessons. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Somali

sense.def: someone who works in a profession such as medicine or law
dictionaryExamples: a medical practitioner
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another measure is to encourage people to do some forms of exercise and this is where health care practitioners come in. International English Language Testing System; C2; Yapese

sense.def: doing things in a practical and realistic way and not using only ideas
dictionaryExamples: a pragmatic approach to a problem
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Anal[yz]ing such opinions, it is not hard to conclude that the younger generation, which is traditionally regarded as romantic and idealistic, has become rather pragmatic and down-to-earth and got[ten] used to associat[ing] success in life with affluenc[e]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to express admiration or approval about the achievements or characteristics of a person or thing
dictionaryExamples: He should be praised for his honesty.
My parents always praised me when I did well at school.
He was highly praised for his research on heart disease.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In fact, my grade was the best in the class and my Math teacher praised me for being so careful and correct. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: words you say to show that you admire someone or something
dictionaryExamples: They deserve praise for their achievements.
Her first novel won a lot of praise from the critics.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This may sound like glowing praise, but Michael really deserves it. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: to speak to a god in order to show your feelings or to ask for something
dictionaryExamples: She knelt and prayed silently.
Let us pray for the victims of this terrible disaster.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It always reminds me when to study, to pray, etc. Key English Test; A2; Bengali

sense.def: to hope for something very much
dictionaryExamples: We're praying for good weather for the parade tomorrow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am very di[sa]ppointed with this event and praying that it will happen again next year. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: the words you say to a god
dictionaryExamples: a prayer of thanks
She always says her prayers  before she goes to sleep.
We thought he'd been killed, but our prayers were answered when he arrived home safely.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am stopping this letter with lots of love and prayers. Preliminary English Test; B1; Malayalam

sense.def: something that you do to prevent bad things happening in the future
dictionaryExamples: Driving alone at night can be dangerous, so always take precautions.
They called the doctor as a precaution.
He took the precaution of locking the door.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The dancing and the horse shows were indeed cancelled, as a precaution out of fear of the weather becoming even worse. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to happen or exist before something else
dictionaryExamples: The formal ceremony was preceded by a parade.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Second, guest appearances should be preceded by the reading and discussion of those writers' works, otherwise students may profit and benefit little from meeting and talking to them [at] such events. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: an action or decision that is used as an example when someone wants to do a similar thing in the future
dictionaryExamples: This decision has set an important legal precedent for other countries.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although it definitely sounds rather optimistic, this precedent might be used to improve one aspect of life in the future: safety and peace. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: rare and very valuable
dictionaryExamples: a precious vase
a precious gift
a precious metal/stone
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am so sorry because I broke a precious vase you had in your bedroom. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: very important to you
dictionaryExamples: a precious moment/memory
His books are his most precious possessions.
Time is precious - don't waste it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Love is something precious which we all want to have. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: exact and accurate
dictionaryExamples: The precise location of the  house is a secret.
He caught me at the precise moment that I fainted.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would appreciate [it] if you were more precise next time with your report. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: used to give exact details about something
dictionaryExamples: We met in 1994 - on October 1st to be precise.
There was a good turnout for the meeting - twelve of us to be precise.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's in Central London, to be precise. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: exactly
dictionaryExamples: The fireworks begin precisely at eight.
What do you think the problem is, precisely?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was born in the countryside, more precisely in Bourgogne, and he had always lived there. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: used to emphasize what you are saying
dictionaryExamples: "You look tired - you should go home and rest."  "I'm going to do precisely that."
But it's precisely because of the noise that they're thinking of moving.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Books may not be interactive, but that's precisely where their advantage is. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: used to agree with what someone else says
dictionaryExamples: "It's not the shape I dislike, it's the color." - "Precisely!"

sense.def: an animal that kills and eats other animals
dictionaryExamples: These animals have remarkably few predators.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Ferocious animals, such as tigers, lions and snakes (anacondas) can be seen in these areas, but for those who are not used to forests, these predators may only become visible once they are attacked. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: the person who was in a job or position before
dictionaryExamples: He seems a lot better than his predecessor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the light of the above-mentioned arguments it remains [all] the more [odd] why my predecessor has chosen decisions concerning friendship and leisure activities as examples of his thesis. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to say that an event or action will happen in the future, especially as a result of knowledge or experience
dictionaryExamples: It's still not possible to accurately predict when an earthquake will occur.
Who could have predicted that within ten years he'd be in charge of the whole company?
The hurricane is predicted to reach the coast tomorrow morning.
No one can predict when/where the disease will strike next.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now, fully equipped and powerful computers can be so small and mobile that some specialists predict that new devices will replace book[s]. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: happening or behaving in a way you expect and not unusual or interesting
dictionaryExamples: Comets appear at predictable times.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I was younger I read many books. I prefer[r]ed m[y]stery stories, but now [they] are very predictable for me. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: when you say what will happen in the future
dictionaryExamples: Please don't ask me to make any predictions about tomorrow's meeting.
No one believed her prediction that the world would end on November 12.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But in case my predictions are right, maybe you should buy a new pair of shorts? First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: more important or noticeable than others
dictionaryExamples: He has played a predominant role in these talks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As far as I know, the predominant wish of students leaving school is to enjoy life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: mostly or mainly
dictionaryExamples: a predominantly Asian community
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nevertheless the Japanese scientist refutes the latter argument on basis of his famous theory, according to which the predominantly masculine pleasure of driving is caused by a "hidden dictator's syndrome." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to like someone or something more than another person or thing
dictionaryExamples: Do you prefer hot or cold weather?
I prefer cats to dogs.
She prefers watching tennis to playing it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Pop music is good but we prefer hip-hop. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: used to say what you want, or to ask someone what they want
dictionaryExamples: I prefer not to discuss this issue.
He said he would prefer to leave early.
Which jacket do you prefer?
I prefer the green one.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would prefer to wear old jeans and [a] top. Key English Test; A2; Tamil

sense.def: better or more suitable
dictionaryExamples: Staying at home is preferable to going out with someone you don't like.
Surely a diplomatic solution is preferable to war.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it would be preferable to do it [i]n July. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: if possible
dictionaryExamples: Water the plants twice a week, preferably in the morning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think you should spend more time with your friends, preferably in the fresh country air. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: when you like something or someone more than another person or thing
dictionaryExamples: We have white and whole wheat bread. Do you have a preference?
Her preference is for comfortable rather than stylish clothes.
I have a preference for sweet food over spicy.
Choosing furniture is largely a matter of personal preference.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please, let us know about his musical preferences, as well as the books that he is interested in. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a letter or group of letters added to the beginning of a word to make a new word
dictionaryExamples: In the word "unimportant," "un-" is a prefix.

sense.def: when a woman is pregnant
dictionaryExamples: Her symptoms were caused by her pregnancy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The reduced risk of further pregnancies in conjunction with less remuneration for their work makes these women seem more attractive to employers. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: A pregnant woman has a baby developing inside her uterus.
dictionaryExamples: She's five and a half months pregnant.
My mother stopped smoking when she became pregnant.
My sister is pregnant with twins.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She wrote me [the] really nice news that she is pregnant. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: an unfair and unreasonable opinion or feeling, especially when formed without enough thought or knowledge
dictionaryExamples: Laws against racial prejudice must be strictly enforced.
He claims that prejudice against immigrants has increased.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What is really amazing is that Biko, who is banned but "free" of any prejudice, who doesn't discriminate [against] anybody, "frees" Mr Woods (who is not banned) from his narrow-minded and intolerant views and gives another aim to Woods' life. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: feeling dislike for a group of people or treating them unfairly because they are a different race, sex, religion, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Are the police prejudiced against black people?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Men have been very prejudiced a[gains]t women in this sector, so it has been hard to prove the opposite. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: done or happening in order to prepare for the main event or activity
dictionaryExamples: a preliminary discussion/meeting
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Picasso would start with a lot of preliminary sketches and then go on to paint his final picture, where the main figures - a woman and a horse - are screaming in despair. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: the land and buildings owned by someone, especially by a company or organization
dictionaryExamples: The company is moving to new premises.
The ice cream is made on the premises.
The security guards escorted the protesters off  the premises.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The staff will have more space to work in as our local branch is moving to larger premises, and better work conditions will be provided to them. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: the things that you do or the time that you spend preparing for something
dictionaryExamples: The teacher was arranging the classroom in preparation for the new students.
The team blamed injuries and lack of preparation for the loss.
Yasmin assisted in the preparation of this article.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I felt that I improved a lot just in this class, so I think that my preparation for the exam will be really good. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: plans or arrangements that you make to prepare for something
dictionaryExamples: wedding preparations
We are making preparations to fly Mr. Goodall to the nearest hospital.
Preparations for the opening ceremony are well under way.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would really like to help you with the preparations the day before, but it's impossible for me to come. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: to make or get something or someone ready for something that will happen in the future
dictionaryExamples: Do you feel prepared for your interview?
This course is intended to prepare students for management positions.
Are the players mentally and physically prepared to play a tough game?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example, I can prepare the materials we will need for decorating.  Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: to make food ready to be eaten
dictionaryExamples: Marco prepared lunch.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can help you to decorate the stage, [and] prepare some snacks. Key English Test; A2; Malay

sense.def: ready to deal with a situation
dictionaryExamples: When she called on me, I wasn't prepared.
They were prepared for the worst.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to be well prepared for my first [trip] to England. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to be willing, or happy to agree to do something
dictionaryExamples: If you need help, I'm prepared to fill out some of the paperwork.
People are not really prepared to talk about personal problems.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm prepared to offer quite a lot in order to give the animals a better life. First Certificate in English; [no level]; [no L1 data]

sense.def: done or made earlier
dictionaryExamples: The spokesperson read a prepared statement.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: More fast-food and prepared meals are available than a few years ago. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: in grammar, a word which is used before a noun, a noun phrase or a pronoun, connecting it to another word
dictionaryExamples: In the sentences "We jumped in the lake," and "She drove slowly down the driveway," "in" and "down" are prepositions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my 1st lesson I learned about prepositions, and I think I'm going to continue the class next week. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to say what medical treatment someone needs
dictionaryExamples: Painkillers are the most common drugs prescribed by doctors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I visited my doctor a few weeks ago in order to ask him if I could get tranquilizers as a remedy, but he refused to prescribe them as they wouldn't fight the real reason for my problems. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a piece of paper on which a doctor writes the details of the medicine or drugs that someone needs
dictionaryExamples: a doctor's prescription
a prescription for sleeping pills
The doctor renewed my prescription for three more months.
This drug is only available by prescription.
My insurance has a very low co-pay for prescription drugs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You should also go to see a doctor and ask him to give a prescription for some sleeping pills. First Certificate in English; B2; Basque

sense.def: when someone or something is in a place
dictionaryExamples: She was anxious about the presence of so many people.
The presence of pollen in the atmosphere causes hay fever in some people.
He's usually quite polite in my presence.
The document was signed in the presence of two witnesses.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Your presence here at the club would be really benefic[ial] for the students. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a quality that makes people notice and admire you
dictionaryExamples: She's only small, but she has real presence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He derived great benefit from her soothing presence, but otherwise was too duty-bound to notice their relationship went haywire. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to have a strong effect on other people
dictionaryExamples: The new police chief has really made his presence felt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Before long a local bicycle gang was formed which would ride all over the village, through fields and gardens, making our presence felt. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a group of police or soldiers who are watching or controlling a situation
dictionaryExamples:
a strong police
                       presence
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People residing in [the] countryside find themselves living in fear, claiming that the lack of police presence and protection has resulted in great insecurity. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a feeling that someone is still in a place although they are not there or are dead
dictionaryExamples: His daughter's presence seemed to fill the empty bedroom.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There was something there that disturbed him, he felt a strange presence but couldn't describe what it was. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: the ability to deal with a difficult situation quickly and effectively
dictionaryExamples: She had the presence of mind to press the alarm.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Frank tried to hide a bag behind his back with great presence of mind. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a talk giving information about something
dictionaryExamples: The speaker gave an interesting presentation on urban transportation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm going to prepare a presentation about London. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: an occasion when prizes, certificates, diplomas, etc. are formally given to those who have won or achieved them
dictionaryExamples: The presentation of prizes and certificates will take place in the auditorium.

sense.def: the way something is arranged or shown to people
dictionaryExamples: Presentation is important if you want people to buy your products.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: While the surroundings are very elegant, this is one restaurant where the food and its presentation is of paramount importance. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: now
dictionaryExamples: He's presently living with his parents.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am presently working as [a] sales assistant in "La Suze," a lingerie shop in the city. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: when you keep something the same or prevent it from being damaged or destroyed
dictionaryExamples: the preservation of peace
the preservation of wildlife
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was asked to investigate the current situation in my area, concerning the efforts to cut down on the use of energy and natural resources, in order to contribute to the preservation of the environment. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to keep something the same or prevent it from being damaged or destroyed
dictionaryExamples: to preserve the environment
We want to preserve the historic buildings downtown.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a fundamental necessity for everybody to try to do something in order to preserve the health of our planet. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: the job of being president, or the period when someone is a president
dictionaryExamples: He has announced that he is running for the presidency.
She won the presidency by a wide margin.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His presidency finished in 1384 (2005), but Iranians will never forget him. First Certificate in English; B2; Farsi

sense.def: the highest political position in some countries, usually the leader of the government
dictionaryExamples: President Obama
the President of France
Thank you, Mr./Madam President.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [An]other attraction is our museum that is very famous because many paintings have been bought by important pe[ople] like the President of the United States. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: relating to the president of a country
dictionaryExamples: a presidential candidate
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Anyway, now Laura was counting to 10 as her brother was putting a bomb in the presidential car. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: to push something firmly, often without causing it to move permanently further away from you
dictionaryExamples: Press the button to start the machine.
He pressed his face against the window.
Press down hard on the pedal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When you press it, it will say: "Congratulations" to you. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: to try hard to persuade someone to do something
dictionaryExamples: The committee pressed him to reveal more information.
We pressed him for an answer but he refused.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A year later, the press, publishers and film-makers and directors pressed me to make a film on Stella. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: to complain officially about someone in a court of law
dictionaryExamples: The family decided not to press charges against him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He decided on the spot that if Paul was to return all the money he wouldn't press charges so he called his parents and asked them to find out where he was. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: newspapers, magazines, and television, radio, or Internet news organizations, or the people who report the news for them
dictionaryExamples: The director hasn't talked to the press yet.

the local/national
                         
                      press

a press
                         
                            conference/briefing
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I helped them with most of the practical arrangements, [such] as meetings with the press, dinners and so on. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: praise or criticism from newspapers, magazines, television, etc.
dictionaryExamples: She's had a lot of bad press recently.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also insist that you wr[i]te a note of apology to the organi[z]ers, for bad press won't help either the charity or the hospital. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: when someone tries to make someone else do something by arguing, persuading, etc.
dictionaryExamples: political/peer pressure
Teachers are under pressure to work longer hours.
He's responding to pressure from local politicians who want the bridge built quickly.
He only asked her under pressure from his wife.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I understand that you must work a lot because of the pressure from your boss, but I will in spite of that warn you and ask you to think over the situation. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to try to force someone to do something
dictionaryExamples: They're putting pressure on me to make a decision.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She puts a lot of pressure on me and beli[e]ves that I can do it in the same way as she did. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: a difficult situation that makes you feel worried or unhappy
dictionaryExamples: They've been putting a lot of pressure on her at work lately.
Be nice to him - he's been under a lot of pressure.
Can you work well under pressure?
the pressures of work
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have two younger sisters so I think I can cope with the pressure [of] helping out in the summer camps. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: the force that a liquid or gas produces when it presses against an area
dictionaryExamples:
water/air
                       pressure
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The process of hydro-electric power generation is using the water pressure from the reservoir to generate the power, which is then transported to [a] transformer station through high voltage cables. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: the force you produce when you press something
dictionaryExamples: He put too much pressure on the door handle and it snapped.
You can stop bleeding by applying pressure close to the injured area.

sense.def: when people feel respect and admiration for you, often because you are successful
dictionaryExamples: His company has gained international prestige.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many companies nowadays are organi[z]ing some cultural or sports events in order to strengthen the company's prestige. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: respected and admired, usually because of being important
dictionaryExamples: a prestigious award
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The jobs that were prestigious in the past seem to be the opposite now. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: used to say what you think is the likely situation
dictionaryExamples: They would presumably be able to afford a larger apartment.
Presumably he just forgot to send the letter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, I would recommend depart[ing] at 8 o'clock because it will presumably be less crowded than at 10 o'clock. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to believe something to be true because it is very likely, although you are not certain
dictionaryExamples: I presume they're not coming, since they haven't replied to the invitation.
You are Dr. Smith, I presume?
"Are we walking to the hotel?" "I presume not/so."
The universe is presumed to contain many other planets with some form of life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Naturally eating habits have changed here - I presume as everywhere else in the western world - but the Austrians still love their "Wiener Schnitzel" and their "Tafelspitz," which are considered typical traditional Austrian food. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: when you believe that something is true without any proof
dictionaryExamples: I object to the presumption that young people are only interested in pop music.
Our justice system is based on the presumption of innocence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All positive effects of the [higher] average age of people have the presumption that their health allows them to live like younger ones. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to behave as if something is true when it is not
dictionaryExamples: She's not really hurt - she's only pretending.
He pretended (that) he didn't mind, but I knew that he did.
Were you just pretending to be interested?
Of course I was angry - I can't pretend otherwise.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Be calm or at least pretend you are. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: If a woman or girl is pretty, she is attractive.
dictionaryExamples: She's got such a pretty daughter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I met a pretty girl and she's called Mary. Key English Test; A2; [no L1 data]

sense.def: If a place or an object is pretty, it is pleasant to look at.
dictionaryExamples: That's a pretty hat you're wearing.
a pretty little village
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Rabat is the capital of Morocco. There [are] a lot of attractions, like ancient historic sites, sandy beaches, [and a] pretty Moroccan market. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: quite, but not extremely or not completely
dictionaryExamples: The house has four bedrooms, so it's pretty big.
I'm pretty sure it was her.
I've got a pretty good idea of how to get there.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The best thing about our club is the table tennis, which I'm getting pretty good at. Preliminary English Test; B1; [no L1 data]

sense.def: almost
dictionaryExamples: I've pretty much finished here.
She knows pretty well everything there is to know on the subject.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can pretty much tell your mother any problem you have and she'll try her best to help you out. First Certificate in English; B2; [no L1 data]

sense.def: to get control or influence
dictionaryExamples: We can only hope that common sense will prevail.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This saying reflects an attitude that prevailed in the European countries of the 19th century when the people were no longer confined to only a basic education and the authority of the church. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to stop something from happening or someone from doing something
dictionaryExamples: to prevent accidents/crime
Members of the public were prevented from entering the building.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As I told you once, I'd like to buy a bookshelf where I can organize my books and prevent them from getting damaged. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: when you stop something from happening or stop someone from doing something
dictionaryExamples: crime prevention
The organization is committed to disease prevention and education.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think prevention is the best medicine. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: Preventive action is intended to stop something before it happens.
dictionaryExamples: preventive measures
preventive medicine
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are many causes to these problems and certain preventive measures should be enforced to solve them. International English Language Testing System; C2; Arabic

sense.def: existing or happening before something or someone else
dictionaryExamples: the previous day/week/month/year
I learned valuable skills in my previous job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I felt my previous class was not suitable for me any longer, [so] I decided to [ask] the administrator to help me to change [to] a higher class. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: before the present time or the time referred to
dictionaryExamples: She was previously employed as a tour guide.
I had mailed the card two months previously.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, first of all I must tell you that I didn't know it previously. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: an animal that is hunted and killed by another animal
dictionaryExamples: The camera follows the owl swooping down on its prey.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Like a tiger who looks [at] the prey he has just hunted, Martha looked at the dead body of the boy. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to be hurt or deceived by something or someone bad
dictionaryExamples: He fell prey to a gang of criminals pretending to be city officials.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As young people do not have experience in living independently in society and are not fully aware of social problems such as drugs and violence, they may easily fall prey to adults who would like to exploit them. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the amount of money that you pay to buy something
dictionaryExamples: high/low prices
Real estate prices are falling/rising.
The price of heating oil has gone up again.
Automakers are offering big price cuts.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please send me some information about the course, with timetables, prices... Skills for Life (Entry 2); [no level]; [no L1 data]

sense.def: the unpleasant results that you must accept or experience for getting or doing something
dictionaryExamples:
Suspension from the club was a high/small 
                          price to pay for his mistake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What really characterizes Michael is his love for life, his continuous joy, which sometimes can become rather annoying, but this is just a small price to pay for all his success. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: If you want something at any price, you will do anything to get it.
dictionaryExamples: She wanted the job at any price.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They wanted to be parents at any price. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: to accept the unpleasant results of what you have done
dictionaryExamples: If you abuse your body now, you'll pay the price when you're older.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When all is said and done, do contemporary sports events pose an advantage to athletes pursuing their physical excellence? I would dare to say no, unless he, or increasingly she, is prepared to pay the price in becoming a ready-made product for public consumption. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: to say what the price of something is
dictionaryExamples: The car is priced at $28,000.
There is a lack of reasonably priced housing for rent.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Both games are priced at approximately £30. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: very valuable
dictionaryExamples: a priceless antique/painting
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She had five unique paintings [by] Van Gogh which were priceless. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: very important or useful
dictionaryExamples: A trip around the world is a priceless opportunity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It would [be] sad if not unfair for my friend to [miss] this unique and priceless opportunity. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a feeling of satisfaction with your achievements or the achievements of your family or friends
dictionaryExamples: She felt a great sense of pride as she watched him accept the award.

The whole community takes 
                          pride in the school.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I take pride in you and your patience. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: the respect that you feel for yourself
dictionaryExamples: She has too much pride to accept any help.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her wou[n]ded pride misleads her into a strong prejudice.  First Certificate in English; B2; Romanian

sense.def: to decide to do something although it will shame or embarrass you
dictionaryExamples: He swallowed his pride and asked if he could have his old job back.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She has had to put up with all the psychological harm that her husband has put her through and at the same time, she has had to keep on struggling for her children, never givin[g] in; holding back her tears, swallowing her pride just for the benefit of her daughters. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: someone who performs religious duties and ceremonies
dictionaryExamples: a Roman Catholic priest
Many in the Anglican Church are still opposed to women priests.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I started to read one of the e-mails and I couldn't believe what I was reading. One of my best friends had become a priest! Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: mainly
dictionaryExamples: She's known primarily as a novelist but she also writes poetry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "The Vagabond Dog" - one of his best short stories - is primarily naturalistic. First Certificate in English; B2; Farsi

sense.def: most important
dictionaryExamples: Her primary responsibility is to train new employees.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can listen to music and generally use it for fun but the primary reason that computer[s] were invented was for communication. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: main or most important
dictionaryExamples: the prime suspect in a murder investigation
a prime source of evidence
The president is a prime  target for the assassin's bullet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is of prime importance to find out about culture and history. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a very good example of something
dictionaryExamples: This is a prime example of what happens when communication is poor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In this context in the analyses of Piggy's character, it strikes me as a first spontaneous impression that he personifies the typical proper schoolboy who will later on undoubtedly grow up to be the prime example of a good and responsible citizen. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: the leader of the government in some countries
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yesterday I heard that animal rights activists have met the prime minister: maybe the situation will change. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: relating to human society at a very early stage of development, with people living in a simple way without machines or a writing system
dictionaryExamples: primitive man
primitive societies
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Young people nowadays are more exposed to the world news, whereas primitive societies were rather isolated and ha[d] nothing to [do] with [the] outside world. International English Language Testing System; C1; Arabic

sense.def: very basic or old-fashioned
dictionaryExamples: The conditions at the campsite were quite primitive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Students will not appreciate their primitive meals at any cost, even a low one. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: the son of a king or queen, or one of their close male relatives
dictionaryExamples: Prince Edward
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At last, the beast really changed back into a prince. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: the daughter of a king or queen, or one of their close female relatives, or the wife of a prince
dictionaryExamples: He was married to a Spanish princess.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My teacher told me that I have to wear a dress like a princess. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: main, or most important
dictionaryExamples: That was my principal reason for moving.
He's a principal dancer with the Houston Ballet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is its principal advantage. Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: the person in charge of a school
dictionaryExamples: She is the principal of Northside Elementary School.
The school board has hired a new principal for the high school.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He said that my school principal would like to see me that day and it was urgent. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a copy of a picture made using photography or by pressing paper onto a design covered in ink
dictionaryExamples: a print of Van Gogh's 'Sunflowers'
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: MI5 operates two computers, one for word processing and another for scanning and reproducing prints, drawings and photos. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: words, letters, or numbers that are produced on paper by a machine
dictionaryExamples: The print's so small in this book that I can hardly read it.

sense.def: If a book is in print, it is possible to buy a new copy of it, and if it is out of print, it is not currently possible.
dictionaryExamples: The novel was first published in 1880 and has been in print ever since.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are books that you would never find again because they are out of print. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: to produce writing or images on paper or other material with a machine
dictionaryExamples: I printed your report and I made some notes on it.
The instructions are printed on the side of the box.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will help you with printing the tickets. Key English Test; A2; Czech

sense.def: to produce books, newspapers, magazines, etc., usually in large quantities, using machines
dictionaryExamples: Fifty thousand booklets have been printed for the exhibition.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We should also have a more efficient tourist service - it [is] years since we last printed brochures of our town! First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to include a piece of writing in a newspaper or magazine
dictionaryExamples: They printed his letter in Tuesday's paper.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please take this into consideration and print a corrected version of the article. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a machine that is connected to a computer and produces writing or images on paper
dictionaryExamples: a laser printer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to sell a computer with a printer. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: existing or happening before something else
dictionaryExamples: The course requires no prior knowledge of Spanish.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Referring to our prior correspondence I would like to inform you that I accept your friendly offer for being once again your interpreter on your one-week-tour through our country. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: before a particular time or event
dictionaryExamples: the weeks prior to her death
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'd like to tell you about my expectations prior to the conference. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: something that is very important and must be dealt with before other things
dictionaryExamples: The people did not seem to consider safety a priority.
My top/highest/first priority is to find somewhere to live.
It's important to have your priorities straight/right.
The school admissions policy is to give priority to students who live in the neighborhood.
Street repair is a priority for the town council.
Official business will have to take priority over personal requests.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We need to show films [that are] enjoyable for all kinds of people, always giving priority to the quality. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a building where criminals must live as a punishment
dictionaryExamples: He's spent a lot of time in prison.
She went to/was sent to prison for six months.
They should put him in prison and throw away the key!
a prison cell/sentence
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: About 3 weeks later, I tried to escape from the prison, but they c[aught] me. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: a person who is kept in prison as a punishment
dictionaryExamples: Prisoners climbed onto the prison roof to protest the conditions inside.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This film dealt with two prisoners that escape from their prison and start to take money from banks (of course not legally!) Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to catch someone and guard them so that they cannot escape
dictionaryExamples: He was taken prisoner by a group of armed soldiers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The ant princess was held prisoner by the evil beetle and the fly prince was on his way to sa[v]e her.  Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: the right to be alone and do things without other people seeing or hearing you
dictionaryExamples: I hate sharing a bedroom - I never get any privacy.
The new law is designed to protect people's privacy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, it seems that a young, modern and successful man can have no privacy at all. First Certificate in English; B2; Czech

sense.def: to try to learn things about someone's private life when they do not want you to
dictionaryExamples: They were fed up with journalists invading their privacy.

sense.def: becoming involved in someone's private life when they do not want you to
dictionaryExamples: These phone calls to my home are an invasion of my privacy.

sense.def: only for one person or group and not for everyone
dictionaryExamples: She has a small, private office.
I caught him looking through my private papers.
We can't play ball here - it's private property.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I went there to see what's going on, and the band invited us to their private party. Preliminary English Test; B1; Serbian

sense.def: describes activities which involve personal matters or relationships and are not connected with your work
dictionaryExamples: Apparently in interviews he refuses to talk about his private life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We talked about the film and also about our work and our private life. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: controlled or paid for by a person or company and not by the government
dictionaryExamples: a private school
The governor is on vacation and traveling as a private citizen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have been working as an English teacher for small children at a private school for three years. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: in a place where nobody else can hear you or see what you are doing
dictionaryExamples: They wanted to talk in private.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I agree that th[is] should be in private. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: in secret, or with only one or two other people present
dictionaryExamples: She spoke privately with the manager.
Despite his public support, privately  he was worried.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll pick you up from the station so we will have the op[p]ortunity to chat privately. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: If an industry or organization owned by the government is privatized, it is sold to private companies.
dictionaryExamples: The government plans to privatize the railroads.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The companies were privati[z]ed or closed down. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: an advantage that only one person or group has, usually because of their position or because they are rich
dictionaryExamples: She was born into a life of privilege.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are only a few things that have been worrying me a bit: firstly I would like to enjoy the privilege of having my own parking [place]. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: an opportunity to do something special or enjoyable
dictionaryExamples: I had the privilege of meeting the Queen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have attended several events in benefit of The Foundation but this one was particular[l]y special and memorable as I had the pleasure and the privilege of meeting Elton again - it is really a great privilege to be friendly with someone so special as he is. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: having an advantage that only one person or group has, usually because of their position or because they are rich
dictionaryExamples: a privileged upbringing
As an ambassador, she enjoys a very privileged status.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Today we [are] so privileged, life has become so easy in many ways. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: having an opportunity to do something special or enjoyable
dictionaryExamples: I was privileged to see her sing in Milan.

sense.def: something given to the winner of a competition or to someone who has done good work
dictionaryExamples: to win a prize
first/second prize
the Nobel Prize for Literature
The committee will award $60,000 in prize money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We played quite a few games and we had prizes for the winner of each of the games. Key English Test; A2; Marathi

sense.def: how likely it is that something will happen
dictionaryExamples: What's the probability of winning?
There's a high probability that he'll get the job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The statistics say that if one woman gets married to one man, the probability that they will get divorced is 50 percent. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: used to mean that something is very likely
dictionaryExamples: She will, in all probability, have left before we arrive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Anybody who can fulfill the above conditions will in all probability be successful. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

dictionaryExamples: The probable cause of death was heart failure.
A June meeting is quite/very probable.
It is probable that prices will continue to fall.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Surely the older you are, the less probable it is that you'll choose a bike. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: used to mean that something is very likely
dictionaryExamples: I'll probably be home by midnight.
I'm probably going - it depends on the weather.
He probably didn't even notice.
Probably the best thing to do is to call them before you go.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll probably be there by 3.30. Key English Test; A2; Greek

sense.def: a situation that causes difficulties and that needs to be dealt with
dictionaryExamples: I'm having problems with my computer.
health/financial problems
