No one has solved the problem of what to do with radioactive waste.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: English and Polish a[c]cents are very diff[e]rent, so this is [a] big problem for me. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: something that you say to mean you can or will do what someone has asked you to do
dictionaryExamples: "Can you get me to the airport by 11:30?" "No problem."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Jo, No problem. I can help you. Key English Test; A2; German

sense.def: something that you say when someone has thanked you for something
dictionaryExamples: "Thanks for taking me home."  "No problem."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's ok, no problem. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: full of problems or difficulties
dictionaryExamples: He has a very problematic relationship with his father.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, there were some problematic issues. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: the official or usual way of doing something
dictionaryExamples: The company has new procedures for dealing with complaints.
You must follow correct procedure at all times.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In conclusion, I would be very grateful if you could send me additional information on the application procedure. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to continue to happen
dictionaryExamples: His lawyers have decided not to proceed with the case.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am not sure which is the best way to proceed with this problem. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: to do something after you have done something else
dictionaryExamples: She sat down and proceeded to tell me about her skiing trip.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Ku wagged her finger in approval and proceeded to explain her plan. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: legal action against someone
dictionaryExamples: The bank is threatening to start legal proceedings against him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I happened to know that Diana Robinson, a 13-year-old girl, had started legal proceedings against Mr Thomson and Mr Ketzo, another teacher. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a written record of what is said or done in a meeting
dictionaryExamples: I read the proceedings of the previous meeting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, I would like to [do] some research [on] Spain's transition to democracy from dictatorship by accessing primary materials such as parliamentary proceedings, newspapers and other main sources available. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: a series of actions that you take in order to achieve a result
dictionaryExamples: the peace process
I didn't know buying a house would be such a long process.
The whole process takes about three months.
This decision may delay the process of European unification.
We're in the process of moving the files to the warehouse.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But the situation is getting worse because of the decisions of the European Union, which is trying to unif[y] the education of Europe without respecting the wishes of the students who are trying to stop this process. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: a series of changes that happen naturally
dictionaryExamples: the ageing process
It's all part of the learning process.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Th[ese] events are not only to entertain students, but they are also a part of the learning process, as by communicating with each other students learn the language. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: If something is being done, and something else happens in the process, the second thing happens as a result of doing the first thing.
dictionaryExamples: She stood up to say hello and spilled her drink in the process.
The tunnel was built, but many lives were lost in the process.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If an attempt is made to move them to another location they will probably die in the process. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

blocks.phrase: be in the process of doing sth

sense.def: to have started doing something
dictionaryExamples: We're in the process of painting our apartment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, I think I [am] still in the process of learning to learn from the past mistakes since I reali[z]e what a great help it might be. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to deal with documents in an official way
dictionaryExamples: Visa applications take 28 days to process.

sense.def: a line of people or vehicles that moves forward slowly as part of a ceremony or public event
dictionaryExamples: a funeral procession
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As Tom was leading the procession, he saw at once the black, forbidding scene. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: to make or grow something
dictionaryExamples: The factory produces about 900 cars a year.
She works for a company that produces  electrical components.
This is a flowering plant that will produce small yellow buds in the spring.
She's asked me to review the project and produce a progress report.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In this club we produce and design the school magazine "freestyle". Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to cause a reaction or result
dictionaryExamples: The medication produced unwanted side-effects.
Her remarks produced an awkward silence.
If used on delicate skin, this cream may produce a stinging sensation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was fascinated by the perfection of the classic[al] sculptures: they were perfectly proportioned, every part was functional to the beauty of the whole sculpture. It's really different [to] looking at them in a book! I suggest everybody [should go and] look at them: it produces a magic effect! First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to show or offer something to someone
dictionaryExamples: One of the men suddenly produced a gun from his pocket.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Robert had produced a bottle of champagne, which they had em[p]tied to the last drop. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: foods such as fruit and vegetables that are grown through farming
dictionaryExamples: local/fresh produce
I want to look in the produce department at the supermarket for some salad greens.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Rosie, like the Mac Manners at The Green Man, use[s] local produce and the result is very mouth-watering indeed. I am particularly fond of her soups, the curried parsnip soup being one of my favorites. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: someone who controls how a film, play, program, or musical recording is made
dictionaryExamples: a movie/TV/film/Hollywood/Broadway producer
a music/record producer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm sure they are going to be very interested in your first steps as an actor, but also in your later career as a film producer. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: a company, country, or person that makes goods or grows food
dictionaryExamples: Australia is one of the world's main producers of wool.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example, in several countries people who live in the countryside actually are the main producers of wheat and also the meat that people need in their daily life. International English Language Testing System; C1; Farsi

sense.def: something that is made or grown to be sold
dictionaryExamples: They make skin-care products.
The product is so good it sells itself.
I'm trying to cut down on dairy products.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can buy leather products too. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: when you make or grow something
dictionaryExamples: Sand is used in the production of glass.
The company's new model will be going into production early next year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: More people can enjoy music than before, because of [the] mass production of recorded music. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: the amount of something that is made or grown by a country or a company
dictionaryExamples: We need to increase production by 20%.
Swedish industrial production has fallen steadily this year.
Wheat production has risen over the years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He became famous because he did a lot of things in this country in a year, like giv[ing] them a good education, [and] increas[ing] their production. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: when someone controls how a film, play, program, or musical recording is made
dictionaryExamples: She's hoping to get into television production.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Indeed, Northwood cinema enables people to discover films from all over the world - from a small Brazilian production to a 3 hour Bollywood movie. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: producing a good or useful result
dictionaryExamples: We had a very productive meeting and worked out a lot of the problems.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some people think that by keeping animals in [a] zoo we can observe them, and try to understand the way they [live]; of course, you can learn things, but it would be more productive to observe them when they are free. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: producing a large amount of goods, food, work, etc.
dictionaryExamples: productive people/employees/workers/members
productive farmland
I'm most productive in the afternoon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When the weather is good, I am in the appropriate mood to be productive at work. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: the rate at which goods are produced or work is done
dictionaryExamples: We need to increase productivity by 50%.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Though time-consuming, these staff would need to undergo re-training to be able to achieve the highest level of productivity, besides getting accustomed to the nick-nacks of the Production Department. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: a type of work that needs special training or education
dictionaryExamples: What's your profession?
He's a doctor by profession.
The report notes that forty per cent of lawyers entering the profession are women.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As I look back at my past, [the] most embarrassing moments in my life seem to have something to do with my profession, which is an interpreter from Hungarian. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: the people who do a type of work considered as a group
dictionaryExamples: The medical profession has expressed concern about the new drug.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One day, [when] I had an exam, the examiner asked me questions about the legal profession. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: Someone is professional if they earn money for a sport or activity that most people do as a hobby.
dictionaryExamples: a professional athlete/musician
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example, I met a boy last week and at the end he told me that h[is] father is a professional football player. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: showing skill and careful attention
dictionaryExamples: a professional attitude
He looks very professional in that suit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My teacher is English, her name is Bronye, she's very professional, and nice. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: relating to a job that needs special training or education
dictionaryExamples: You need talent and training to play professional sports.
If your ankle is still hurting maybe you should get professional help.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to play safe by saying that I am not an architect, therefore I am not able to give professional advice. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: someone who earns money for playing a sport or doing an activity that most other people do as a hobby
dictionaryExamples: She has qualified to compete as a professional.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, I wondered whether it would be possible to explain how long it take[s] an amateur to become a professional. Despite  know[ing] almost nothing about tennis I would like to win a championship in the future.First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: someone who does a job that needs special training or education
dictionaryExamples: health professionals
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Computer skills and knowledge are really important for researchers and media professionals. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: a teacher of the highest rank in a department of a British university, or a teacher of high rank in an American university or college
dictionaryExamples: Professor Stephen Hawking
a professor of sociology
a sociology professor
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To put it in a nutshel[l] I was astonished [at] how they weren't able to get on using that assortment of high ranked university professors of social science, and were requiring my help. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: a short description of a person, organization, etc., giving the main details about them
dictionaryExamples: He's updated his Facebook profile.
We include a photograph and short profile of all the candidates.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope [the] above information suits the profile of [the] person you are looking for [for] the job. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the amount of public attention that someone or something receives
dictionaryExamples: The firm has a high profile due to the recent media coverage.
The advertising campaign aims to raise the profile of the company.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I believe that this is a great idea, as it will help raise the profile of our club in our college, and therefore may help increase interest in the club and possibly its membership. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to try not to be noticed
dictionaryExamples: She has kept a low profile since the divorce.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, I believe that the best way to handle these issues is to try to keep a low profile at all times and to remain indifferent to gossip. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: money that you get from selling goods or services for more than they cost to produce or provide
dictionaryExamples: She makes a big profit recycling cloth to sell to textile companies.
Company profits are down against last year's figures.
He sold his house at a huge profit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Also, supermarket owners have put in a vast amount of money to find out the best way to [display] goods in order to get the most profit. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: resulting in or likely to result in a profit or an advantage
dictionaryExamples: Over the years it has developed into a highly profitable business.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is [a] very profitable business. First Certificate in English; B2; Bulgarian

sense.def: useful or likely to give you an advantage
dictionaryExamples: a profitable discussion
I made profitable use of my time, mixing with a lot of different people and practicing my Spanish.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The 'language-shower', as it is called, can sometimes be more productive, efficient and profitable in terms of assimilating knowledge than any course given by highly est[eem]ed professors. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: in a profound way
dictionaryExamples: I think this approach is profoundly misguided.
Her recent songs have been profoundly influenced by current events.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my opinion the reason why Olivia left Douglas was not so much that she didn't love him as the fact that she was profoundly bored by the life she conducted in India. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: a show on television or radio
dictionaryExamples: Did you see that program about spiders last night?
It's my favorite TV program - I never miss it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you liked that program, you should check [the] Discovery Channel, although I don't watch it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a series of instructions which can be put into a computer in order to make it perform an operation
dictionaryExamples: a computer program
She's written a program to find words which frequently occur together.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In this lesson, we are t[a]ught with interactive material. For example, the other day we used this computer program where we could change the sentences and see the different meanings. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a plan of events or activities with a particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: Jesse has started a training program and hopes to run the  New York Marathon next year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mathematics and Physics are the most important part[s] of our program. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: someone who writes computer programs as a job
dictionaryExamples: We employ six programmers on the project.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm a 35-year old programmer in a small company. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: when someone writes computer programs
dictionaryExamples: We learned how to do programming.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am mostly interested in computer graphics and general purpose programming. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: development and improvement of skills, knowledge, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I don't feel that I'm making much progress in learning Spanish.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will check new words, the[ir] meanings and pronunciations, to make progress for missed sessions. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: happening or being done now
dictionaryExamples: Repair work is in progress on several roads including I-78, and will continue until June.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [In] the lower part of your advertisement, it also said there was a theate[r] restaurant, [but] in fact, it was closed because internal decoration was in progress. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to improve or develop in skills, knowledge, etc.
dictionaryExamples: My Spanish never really progressed to fluency.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have to warn you than I'm not an expert in terms of musical basics, but I'm eager to learn them because I know no-one can progress without learning them; so the main job will be to do that. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to continue gradually
dictionaryExamples: I began to feel more relaxed as the evening progressed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As the evening progressed we got to see some of the local dances as well as [a] play performed by a band of gypsies. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: when something or someone changes to the next stage of development
dictionaryExamples: a logical/natural progression
Drugs can stop the progression of the disease.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sharing information between people is a crucial point of peoples' education and it can help in their career progression. International English Language Testing System; C1; Pashto

sense.def: thinking or behaving in a new or modern way
dictionaryExamples: progressive ideas/attitudes
a progressive school
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hear [that] some progressive companies don't really approve of company cars and are trying to keep them to [a] minimum. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: developing or happening gradually
dictionaryExamples: There's been a progressive decline in the standard of living over the past few years.
a progressive disease
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was not a quick change, on the contrary it was a progressive change which was accelerated by some factors during the last two decades. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to officially forbid  something
dictionaryExamples: Trucks are prohibited from driving on the parkways.
Taking photographs inside the museum  is prohibited.
State law prohibits the use of cell phones while driving.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Perhaps we should prohibit the traffic and create a new cheap bus service for the inhabitants and the tourists. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a piece of school work that involves detailed study of a subject
dictionaryExamples: He's doing a class project on pollution.
Everyone had to do a special project for our biology class.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I need my laptop because I saved my school project [o]n it. Key English Test; A2; Tamil

sense.def: a carefully planned piece of work that has a particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: a scientific research project
My next project is decorating the kitchen.
Her latest project is a film based on the life of a nineteenth-century artist.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is also related to my research project. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: a calculation or guess about the future based on information that you have
dictionaryExamples: government projections of population growth
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Japan, on the other side, had a slight decrease [from] 1940 to 1960, very little increase 1960 to 1980, and then it goes up to be the highest country that has population aged 65 and over (2040 projection: more than 25%). International English Language Testing System; C1; Indonesian

sense.def: when a movie or an image is projected onto a screen or wall
dictionaryExamples: the projection of moving images
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Talks and slide projection could be interesting for [o]lder people but not so exciting for younger people, who would prefer some more "active" entertainment like visits to discos, barbecues, quiz night, karaoke nights, fancy-dress parties and other similar happenings. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to make something last longer
dictionaryExamples: Eating a good diet can prolong your life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, nobody expects the strike to be prolonged for more than a week. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: continuing for a long time
dictionaryExamples: a prolonged illness
Avoid prolonged exposure to the sun.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What surprised us was the prolonged delay we had to suffer during our departure from Heathrow. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: important or famous
dictionaryExamples: a prominent figure in history
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It starts with two very important works of Albrecht Durer, one of the most prominent painters of his time, not only in Germany. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: very easy to see or notice
dictionaryExamples: New books are displayed in a prominent position at the front of the store.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A large map of Cyprus holds a prominent place in his store. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to say that you will certainly do something or that something will certainly happen
dictionaryExamples: She promised to write to me every week.
He promised faithfully to call me every week.
Paul promised me that he'd cook dinner tonight.
"I'll come by and see you every day," she promised.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I promise that I will cover the work that you've done in class and I will send [it] to you the day after. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: to say that you will certainly give something to someone
dictionaryExamples: They promised us a reward.
Grandma's ring was promised to me.
Her parents promised her a new car if she passed her exams.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And as a good friend, he has promised me a[n] invitation to [the] wedding. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: If something promises to be good, exciting, etc., people expect that it will be good, exciting, etc.
dictionaryExamples: It promises to be a really exciting game.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm looking forward to start[ing] this trip with you and Chris. It promises to be very exciting! First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: when you say that you will certainly do something
dictionaryExamples: I'll put my things away tonight - and that's a promise!
I'm not sure I can do it so I won't make any promises.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Don't forget your promise to not just visit but stay at my place. Preliminary English Test; B1; Bengali

sense.def: to do/not do what you said that you would do
dictionaryExamples: If I make a promise, I like to keep it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In addition, you didn't keep your promise. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: likely to be very good or successful in the future
dictionaryExamples: a promising student
a promising start to the game
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Secondly, increasing public transportation, such as buses, trains, and etc., is another promising measure. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: to give someone a more important job in the same organization
dictionaryExamples: If I'm not promoted within the next two years, I'm going to change jobs.
She's just been promoted to senior sales rep.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She invited me to a party because her husband had been promoted in his job. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to advertise something
dictionaryExamples: The band is promoting their new album.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At that moment I and a large number of people behind me discovered that I was talking to a person made out of wax. [It] was there to promote the museum. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to encourage something to happen or develop
dictionaryExamples: to promote peace
It has long been known that regular exercise promotes all-around good health.
Greenpeace works to promote awareness of the dangers that threaten our planet today.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A notable exception is the advertising of so-called "slow-food" restaurants, which promote [a] healthy lifestyle. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: when someone is given a more important job in the same organization
dictionaryExamples: Did Steve get the promotion he wanted?
The job offers excellent promotion prospects.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to congratulate you [o]n your promotion. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: activities to advertise something
dictionaryExamples: a sales promotion
They're giving away free T-shirts as a special promotion.
As sales manager, he'll be very involved in promotion and marketing of the product.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: About the meal pointed out in your leaflet, could you tell me if it's a part of the offer and is the breakfast included in the promotion too? First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: when you encourage something to happen or develop
dictionaryExamples: the promotion of a healthy lifestyle
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like an education more based on the needs of the country, but not only on the economic ones but also on the spiritual ones, such as the development of a cultural identity, the promotion of the arts, and the encouragement of an ecologically friendly way of producing wealth for the country as a whole. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: done or acting quickly and without waiting, or arriving at the correct time
dictionaryExamples: prompt payment
a prompt reply
His prompt action certainly saved my life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I look forward to your prompt reply. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to make someone decide to say or do something
dictionaryExamples: What prompted you to say that?
I don't know what prompted him to leave.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What really touched my heart and prompted me to write this letter was the recently published series of articles about favorite possessions. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: quickly, without delay, or at the arranged time
dictionaryExamples: We have to leave promptly  if we want to catch that train.
We try to answer readers' letters as promptly  as we can.
She promised she'd keep it secret and promptly  went and told Ben!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It provides a business lunch which is not very expensive and is served promptly. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a word that is used instead of a noun or a noun phrase
dictionaryExamples: Pronouns are often used to refer to a noun that has already been mentioned.
"She," "it" and "who" are all examples of pronouns.

sense.def: to make the sound of a letter or word
dictionaryExamples: How do you pronounce your last name?
She pronounced his name so badly he didn't even recognize it.
Sade, pronounced "shah-day," is a singer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: During the lesson many foreign students discover how to pronounce words in English. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: how words are pronounced
dictionaryExamples: Mario's English pronunciation is excellent.
There are two different pronunciations of this word.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My teacher is a friendly young man called Peter. He comes from Scotland and this means that his accent and pronunciation are quite different. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a fact or a piece of information that shows something exists or is true
dictionaryExamples: She showed us her passport as proof of her identity.
You need to bring proof that you live in the town to get a library card.
Keep your receipt as proof of purchase.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The smile of a child is the best proof of the utility of zoos. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: information or ideas, which are often false, that an organization prints or broadcasts to make people agree with what it is saying
dictionaryExamples: political   propaganda
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It  is clear that photographs, just as TV, can show the truth while at the same time concealing it. [...] It is a sign of the degree of democracy in a society, whether they act as reliable witnesses or as tools of propaganda. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: correct or suitable
dictionaryExamples: the proper way to do something
Please put those books back in their proper place.
With proper care, that wound will heal without a scar.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is unable to speak proper English. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: correctly, or in a satisfactory way
dictionaryExamples: It's still not working properly.
I'm not properly dressed for this sort of weather.
Come on, Evie, speak properly - you're not a baby any more!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unfortunately my bicycle is not working properly, so I was just wondering if I could borrow yours[?] Preliminary English Test; B1; Hindi

sense.def: a word or group of words that is the name of a person or place and always begins with a capital letter
dictionaryExamples: "London" is a proper noun.

sense.def: objects that belong to someone
dictionaryExamples: The books you borrow remain the property of the library.
The club does not accept responsibility for loss of or damage to club members' personal property.
Children need to be taught to have respect for other people's property.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All at once, they abandoned their sacks of stolen property and ran for their lives! First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: a building or area of land
dictionaryExamples: He owns a number of properties in the downtown area.
The notice said "Private Property, Keep Off."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But the villager[s] left the[i]r homes and all [t]his property and migrated towards cities in search of better facilities. International English Language Testing System; B2; Urdu

sense.def: a part of a total number or amount
dictionaryExamples: Children make up a large proportion of the world's population.
The class consists of men and women in roughly equal proportions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Still, a great proportion of those surveyed mentioned your friendly staff as your strong point. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: If something is out of proportion, it is much bigger or smaller than it should be, when compared to other things.
dictionaryExamples: The punishment is completely out of proportion to the crime.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you were doing it to make a profit, I could understand, but for a library it is just out of proportion [and] I even believe more people could be attracted [if] the prices decrease. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: If something changes in proportion to another thing, it changes to the same degree as that thing.
dictionaryExamples: Your tax payment increases in proportion to your salary.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One aspect of the question is the fact that a sportsman's salary is supposedly not in proportion to the number of hours he work[s]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: a suggestion for a plan
dictionaryExamples: a proposal to raise taxes
The proposal for a new football stadium was rejected.
State legislators questioned the proposal to decrease unemployment benefits.
A proposal that would include moderate income housing and a shopping mall is being considered.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like you to consider my proposal [and] give me [your] response as soon as possible. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: when someone asks someone to marry them
dictionaryExamples: As a young woman, she received several proposals.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After this, things went perfectly well, and Mary accepted his proposal to marry him. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: to suggest a plan or action
dictionaryExamples: I propose that we delay our decision until we have more information.
proposed changes
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think [the] most important [thing] is that you understand our language. So I propose that you [attend] a school for the first two month[s]. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: to intend to do something
dictionaryExamples: They propose to cycle across Iowa.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I propose to build a new hotel following the traditional architecture of the village. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: to ask someone to marry you
dictionaryExamples: He proposed to me on my birthday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First he caught everybod[y's] attention and straightaway he proposed marriage to her. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: suggested as an idea or plan
dictionaryExamples: The proposed road would cut right through the forest.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will need information about the price of the proposed vacation. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: an offer or suggestion, usually in business
dictionaryExamples: an attractive/interesting proposition
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you will consider this proposition positively, then we w[ould] like to produce a deal for you to become our only importer in Britain. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: to officially accuse someone of committing a crime in a court of law, or (of a lawyer) to try to prove that a person accused of committing a crime is guilty of that crime
dictionaryExamples: Shoplifters will be prosecuted.
He was prosecuted for fraud.
The victim has said that she will not prosecute.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, if our only worry is making money, we could be tempted to get involved in black [market] business, [but]  that way we would run the risk of being prosecuted and brought to justice. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a lawyer who prosecutes people
dictionaryExamples: Prosecutors allege that she knew about the plan.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, it was after her graduation that her life began to change: she [took] a Public Examination in order to become a prosecutor. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: the possibility that something good might happen in the future
dictionaryExamples: Is there any prospect of the weather improving?
Job prospects for graduates in the sciences are good.
We've been warned that there is a prospect of flooding due to the heavy rains.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With our effort, I am sure things will be realize[d] and the prospect is [bright]. First Certificate in English; B2; Vietnamese

sense.def: the possibility of being successful
dictionaryExamples: The course will improve his career prospects.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I could learn many things from picking fruit and vegetables and improve my job prospects. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: the idea of something that will happen in the future
dictionaryExamples: We face the prospect of having to start all over again.
I'm very excited at the prospect of seeing her again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They were bewildered at the prospect of beginning a new life there. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: If a person or business prospers, they do well, especially financially.
dictionaryExamples: The government needs to create conditions where business can prosper.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The standards have to be readjusted to give the old and experienced members of society a new role in which they can prosper and still contribute to the benefit of all.  Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: when a person or group of  people is successful, usually by earning a lot of money
dictionaryExamples: Our nation's prosperity comes from oil.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a typical tradition and the rice means prosperity for the couple. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: successful, usually by earning a lot of money
dictionaryExamples: He is a prosperous car dealer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course our employees will also benefit from the company becoming more prosperous. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: someone whose job is having sex with people
dictionaryExamples: There were a lot of prostitutes working in the area.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some people say they are prostitutes while others deny it. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: the main character in a play, movie, or story
dictionaryExamples: The protagonist is a singer named "Jed."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The male protagonist, Anatolij Wonoseltsen, a divorcee with two children, abandoned by his wife, is hoping to get a promotion to be able to provide for the family. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to keep someone or something safe from something dangerous or bad
dictionaryExamples: clothing that protects you against the cold
It's important to protect your skin from the harmful effects of the sun.
Public pressure to protect the environment is strong and growing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hats protect me from the sun (my skin is very sensitive to the sun) and they are also pretty cool. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the act of protecting or state of being protected
dictionaryExamples: Development of land near the reservoirs is restricted for the protection of the water supply.
Their tent gave/offered little protection against the severe storm.
These new laws still don't offer enough protection for many endangered species.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had to write an article about the protection of our environment and it seems that mine was the best! First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: giving protection
dictionaryExamples: protective clothing
a protective mask
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Besides, I don't want to wear any protective head-gear, which all the riders are obliged to wear. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: wanting to protect someone from criticism, hurt, danger, etc. because you like them
dictionaryExamples: It's easy to be too protective towards/of your children.
She's fiercely protective of the man she married 29 years ago.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is very protective with children [in] her custody and can get very aggressive to protect them from strangers or dogs. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: food such as meat, cheese, fish, or eggs that is necessary for the body to grow and be strong
dictionaryExamples: Nuts and fish both contain protein.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In miso soup, a lot of ingredients which have protein are used, and protein is a useful element to keep our body healthy. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: when people show that they disagree with something by standing somewhere, shouting, carrying signs, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a public protest against the war

a peaceful/violent
                      
                   protest
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I believe that we could force the authorities to do something for us by joining [together] in a very big protest. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to show that you disagree with something by standing somewhere, shouting, carrying signs, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Why are those people protesting outside the administration building?
Groups of students have been protesting against the tuition increase.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Undoubtedly, the human rights' defenders would protest. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to say something forcefully or complain about something
dictionaryExamples: They protested, but no one would listen.
The young child protested that she didn't want to leave her mother.
A lot of people protested to the city council about the proposed parking regulations.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'd also like to point out that although the service is pleasant, it's a bit slow, which often makes the customers impatient and leads them to protest. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: feeling very pleased about something you have done, something you own, or someone you know
dictionaryExamples: She was so proud of her son.
I'm very proud to be involved in this project.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Anyway I am so happy to hear that. I'm really proud of you. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: to not be able to do something, especially ask for help, because you are too embarrassed
dictionaryExamples: He's too proud to ask you for any money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She didn't want people to see her like this. She was too proud, too proud... First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: in a way that shows you are pleased about something you have done, something you own, or someone you know
dictionaryExamples: He proudly held out his trophy for us to admire.
There were photographs of all her children proudly displayed on the mantelpiece.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My friend" said John proudly "If you have the right connections, nothing is impossible." First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to show that something is true
dictionaryExamples: Can you prove that you weren't there?
They proved his innocence.
That theory was never proven.
He's always trying to prove something.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was real[l]y stressful because I wanted to prove that the level of my English is high enough for this class but I was too nervous to speak cor[r]ectly. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: to show a particular result or quality after a period of time
dictionaryExamples: The operation proved a complete success.
The new treatment has proved to be very effective.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: John proved to be a good friend and I really thank him for what he did for me. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to show that you are good at something
dictionaryExamples: I wish he'd stop trying to prove himself all the time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Two weeks ago his coach had told him: "Morisson, you're going to play No.9 on Saturday against United, and it's going to be your last chance to prove yourself." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a famous phrase or sentence which gives you advice
dictionaryExamples: an ancient Chinese proverb
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A well-known proverb says: "You should eat to live and not live to eat". Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Bulgarian

sense.def: to give someone something that they need
dictionaryExamples: This brochure  provides useful information about/on the new health insurance plans.
Coffee and tea are provided during the break.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The restaurant provides excellent service. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: to make plans in order to deal with a possible event in the future
dictionaryExamples: We must provide for depreciation when calculating the costs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is difficult to tell what or who should provide for retired workers in the future. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: if, or only if
dictionaryExamples: He's welcome to come along, provided he behaves himself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It offers special services for student[s], such as a welcome drink and a cheap price for the room, provided you show your student card. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: someone who provides something
dictionaryExamples: an Internet service provider
The bank is now a major provider of financial services to industry.
Until her illness she was the main provider  in the family.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to complain a[bou]t my gas and electricity provider Energy Plus. Skills for Life (Level 2); C1; Polish

sense.def: one of the large areas which some countries are divided into because of the type of government they have
dictionaryExamples: the Canadian province of Alberta
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Actually, it was never my intention to cross North America from coast to coast, but to travel around some cities in the provinces of Ontario and Quebec. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: relating to or typical of the provinces
dictionaryExamples: a provincial town
provincial attitudes
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Tolerance and affection were there to[o], but living in a provincial part of France, I remember quite a number of old-fashion[ed] thoughts that I disliked strongly. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: when something is provided
dictionaryExamples: The provision of good public transportation will be essential for developing the area.
When designing buildings in this area, you have to make provisions for earthquakes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Following serious complaints from students, I have read through the three proposals given to me regarding provision of food in the institute. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: when someone makes you angry
dictionaryExamples: He'll start a fight at the slightest provocation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He carried out his professional duties with dignity and under the most severe provocation. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to cause a strong and usually angry reaction
dictionaryExamples: to provoke an argument
Her statement has provoked a public outcry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On their coming back, they show these pictures to their neighbors to provoke the feelings of jealousy mixed with admiration. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: when something is near to something else
dictionaryExamples: What's good about this hotel is its proximity to the airport.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In conclusion it can be said that the Schelde is a very interesting river which gives its surrounding citizens quite a few positive and negative reasons for living in its proximity. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: a doctor who is trained in psychiatry
dictionaryExamples: He was referred to a psychiatrist.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is a psychiatrist, she is doing her degree in geology. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: relating to the human mind and feelings
dictionaryExamples: psychological problems
He claims that the constant aircraft noise has a bad psychological impact/effect on the residents.
We are concerned with the physical and psychological well-being of our employees.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To sum up, taking up team sports [is important] for school children as they are provided with important psychological and social [experiences] vital for their lives. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: in a way that is connected to a person's psychological state
dictionaryExamples: They are bright, happy children and healthy both physically and psychologically.
psychologically damaged
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It makes us like robots and [we] feel bad psychologically, because we want to be different and free [to wear what we want]. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: someone who studies the human mind and human emotions and behavior, and how different situations have an effect on them
dictionaryExamples: a child psychologist
an educational psychologist
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some psychologists claim that forcing pupils to study subjects they don't like can be frustrating for them or even reduce their intellectual potential. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: the scientific study of the way the human mind works and how it influences behavior, or the influence of a particular person's character on their behavior
dictionaryExamples: She studied psychology at Harvard.
a professor of psychology
child psychology
the psychology of risk
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it would be a nice experience for me because I am studying psychology. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a type of bar where you can get beer and other drinks and usually Irish- or English-style food
dictionaryExamples: There's a nice pub called The Old Toad in Rochester.
an Irish/English pub
This place is a brew pub - they make their own beers right here.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Today, advertising has promoted a lot the Irish culture with pubs. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: provided by the government from taxes to be available to everyone
dictionaryExamples: public schools/education
a public library
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you want to join us, we'll meet at 7 pm in front of [the] public library. Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: relating to or involving people in general, rather than being limited to a particular group of people
dictionaryExamples: Public opinion  has turned against him.
Is it really in the public interest  to publish this information?
We need to increase public awareness of the need to get a flu shot.
The results will not be made public  until tomorrow.
We will not go public with  the results until tomorrow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to add that when it comes to public opinion there is a great variety of different points of view - that is why this article, which asserts that "performers were second-rate,'' seems to be unfair. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: an announcement/appearance/statement, etc. that can be seen or heard or known by everyone
dictionaryExamples: The governor is due to make a public statement later today.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Therefore, Gonzalo never attempted to make a public statement to defend himself and underestimated the harm it could cause to his public image. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to allow everyone to know about something
dictionaryExamples: The government does not plan to make its findings public.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: According to the scientific method of research, one should only make a discovery or conclusion public after deep testing and, even after th[at], this fact sh[ould] never be taken as the most complete and definitive truth about any given subject. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: all ordinary people
dictionaryExamples: The public has a right to know about this.
The park is open to the public  until sunset.
When will the book be available to the general public?
Members of the public were asked about their shopping habits.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That is great, because [during] this season a lot of towns usually celebrate and have parties in which you can dance, drink, eat and do one of the several activities that they offer to the public. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: in a place where other people, especially people you do not know, can hear you and see what you are doing
dictionaryExamples: He shouldn't behave like that in public.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This shyness makes it hard for me to speak in public, or even to go out with my friends as often as I should. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to be famous and often featured in the media
dictionaryExamples: Her new role means that she will be in the public eye.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But being famous also means that you are always in the public eye, which is a major drawback. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: a book, magazine, newspaper or document in which information or stories are published
dictionaryExamples: Our latest publication is a magazine for surfers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Sir, I am taking the opportunity to write to you [as] I used your publication "The Student Tourist Guidebook" during my last trip to Lampton. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: the act of making information or stories available to people in a printed form
dictionaryExamples: The brochure will be ready for publication in September.
Will you arrange for publication of the names of the winners?
When is the publication date?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First, I would like to thank you for the publication of [this] article. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: advertising or information about someone or something in the newspaper, on television, etc.
dictionaryExamples: bad/good publicity
We've planned an exciting publicity campaign.
The band's arrival in a hot-air balloon was just a publicity stunt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm sure they will come thanks to the publicity the Festival had this year. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: If something is done publicly, it is done so that everyone can know about it
dictionaryExamples: The company publicly apologized and agreed to contribute some money to charity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It would be a sound opportunity for our singers to perform their new albums and make their work publicly known. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a system of vehicles such as buses and trains which operate at regular times on fixed routes and are used by the public
dictionaryExamples: What's needed is better public transportation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I strongly recommend you to use public transportation in order to get there, [be]cause you may find other types of transportation quite expensive. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to make information available to people, especially in a book, magazine or newspaper, or to produce and sell a book, magazine or newspaper
dictionaryExamples: She just had an article published in their weekend supplement.
The government published unemployment figures quarterly.
The names of the winners will be published in the Sunday paper.
She was only 19 when her first novel was published.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On[e] of his stor[ies] was published by the weekly newspaper. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: a company or person who prepares and prints books, newspapers, magazines, etc.
dictionaryExamples: He works for a publisher in Edinburgh.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, I think that publishers are so worried about their earnings that the[y] don't pay attention to new writers. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a sweet, soft food made from milk, sugar, eggs and flavoring and usually eaten cold
dictionaryExamples: chocolate/vanilla/butterscotch pudding
I made rice pudding for dessert.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And of course, while Italy is exporting pizza, spaghetti and foods like that, Italian people are able to try different food from foreign countries, like hamburger, Chinese food or pudding. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to take hold of something and move it toward you
dictionaryExamples: He pulled the box across the floor to the door.
He pulled her out of the water.
A small child was pulling at her sleeve.
Don't pull Ellie's hair!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The man that pulled me into the house had a familiar face but I didn't recogni[z]e him. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to take hold of something and use physical effort to remove it from somewhere
dictionaryExamples: I pulled the plug out.
He pulled off his sweater.
I spent the morning pulling up the weeds in the flowerbeds.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My tv is broken because of my little sister: she pulled out the cable. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to take hold of something and use effort to move your body forward or up
dictionaryExamples: She pulled herself up the stairs, holding onto the rail.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Rollo and the police ran after him and then Rollo fired wounding Harry, who started to pull himself up the stairs to a manhole above his head and then he died. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to injure a muscle by stretching it too much
dictionaryExamples: I pulled a muscle in my leg when I was skiing.

sense.def: to work as hard as other people in a group
dictionaryExamples: The rest of the team complained that Sarah wasn't pulling her weight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For instance, before your kin get all nice and comfortable, you could ask them to pull their weight around the house by doing a few jobs. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to secretly use the influence that you have over important people to get something or to help someone
dictionaryExamples: I may be able to pull a few strings, if you need the money urgently.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This isn't secret: I thought some of these ideas might be of interest and perhaps an article about them [i]n your newspaper would pull the necessary strings at the City Hall to produce some very much needed changes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

blocks.phrasalVerb: pull down sth or pull sth down

sense.def: to destroy a building
dictionaryExamples: They pulled down the warehouse to build a new supermarket.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In addition to that, I'd do [my] very best to persuade the city council to arrange for the old, ugly houses to be pulled down as quickly as possible. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: If a vehicle pulls in or pulls into somewhere, it moves in that direction and stops there.
dictionaryExamples: They just pulled into the driveway.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He killed her and threw her body out of the train not far from the station, when the train [was] pulling in. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: If a vehicle pulls out, it starts moving onto a road or onto a different part of the road.
dictionaryExamples: That car pulled out right in front of me.

sense.def: If a vehicle pulls over, it moves to the side of the road and stops.
dictionaryExamples: I was looking for somewhere to pull over so I could look at the map.

sense.def: If a vehicle pulls up, it stops, often for a short time.
dictionaryExamples: A car pulled up outside the bank and two men got out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was walking home late one evening, when a car pulled up alongside me. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a warm piece of clothing that covers the top of your body and is pulled on over your head
dictionaryExamples: a black, wool pullover
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My favorite pullover is one with small hearts. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: the regular movement of blood through your body when your heart is beating
dictionaryExamples:
She put her fingers on my wrist to take my pulse 
                         (=count the number of beats per minute).
My pulse rate is 70.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays, stressful things are all around you. They have bad effects on your work, private life or education, as well as sometimes causing you health problems such as high blood pressure, an irregular pulse, etc. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

blocks.phrase: have/keep your finger on the pulse

sense.def: to be/stay familiar with the most recent changes or improvements
dictionaryExamples: The situation changes daily, so you've got to keep your finger on the pulse.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It wouldn't be clever to hire people who are completely ignora[nt] about music and they must constantly keep their finger on the pulse of [the] music industry. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a piece of equipment which is used to cause liquid, air or gas to move from one place to another
dictionaryExamples: a water/gas pump
Can I borrow your bicycle pump?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You need to connect a[n] oxygen pump supplying oxygen [which is] require[d] by goldfish. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: when you hit someone or something with your fist
dictionaryExamples: a punch on the nose
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He gave me a punch and we started to fight. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to hit someone or something with your fist
dictionaryExamples: He punched him in the stomach.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She start[ed] crying and she punched me! First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: the use of punctuation marks in writing so that people can see when a sentence begins and ends, that something is a question, etc.
dictionaryExamples: His letter was completely without punctuation.

sense.def: to make someone suffer because they have done something bad
dictionaryExamples: Those responsible for these crimes must be brought to court and punished.
He punished the class by giving them extra work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll be punished by my parents, because [I told them] a lie. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: when someone is punished
dictionaryExamples: He had to stay in his bedroom as a punishment for fighting.
Many people think that the death penalty is too severe a punishment for any crime.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was punished, nearly expel[led], but Pat didn't receive any punishment. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a person who is being taught, especially in a class
dictionaryExamples: elementary school pupils
The number of pupils in the school system is growing.
She's a former pupil of mine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The other pupils seemed really nice and we had a very interesting lesson. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: a young dog
dictionaryExamples: a litter of puppies
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I came with my mum, dad and brother. We took our puppy also. Preliminary English Test; B1; Singhalese

sense.def: to buy
dictionaryExamples: Tickets must be purchased two weeks in advance.
She purchased her first house with the money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course I was able to purchase a second-hand one but I thought that it was a good investment to have a new computer with up-to-date software. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: something that you buy
dictionaryExamples: How do you wish to pay for your purchases?
a major purchase
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I guess, you are right, I did not tell you last week about my plan concerning my future purchase. Now I'm sure, I'd like to buy a bicycle. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: the act of buying something
dictionaryExamples: New restrictions have been placed on the purchase of land near the reservoir.
A house is the most expensive purchase that most people ever make.
No purchase is necessary to enter this contest.
To receive a refund, you must return the items along with the receipt as  proof of purchase.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Report on the purchase of English videos First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: A pure substance is not mixed with anything else.
dictionaryExamples: pure gold
a pure cotton shirt
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Its domes are made of pure copper, inside there's a big bell called "Zygmunt". First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: clean and healthy
dictionaryExamples: The mountain air was wonderfully pure.
The water isn't chemically pure.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The weather is sunny, the gentle breeze is pure and fresh. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: used to emphasize that a feeling, quality, or state is completely and only that thing
dictionaryExamples:
pure
                   coincidence
Her face had a look of pure delight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It switches your mind off and stre[t]ches all your muscles at the same time. It's pure refreshment! First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: only
dictionaryExamples: She married him purely for his money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And we had to arrange our social programme purely by ourselves. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: the quality of being pure
dictionaryExamples: It is important to preserve the purity of our air and water.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The beauty, purity and power of Chinese poems is hard to resist. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: of a dark reddish blue color
dictionaryExamples: purple plums
a dark purple bruise
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's pink with purple stars. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a dark reddish blue color
dictionaryExamples: Purple is my favorite color.
The evening sky was full of purples and reds.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm going to use pink in my bedroom, purple in the living room and white in the kitchen. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: why you do something or why something exists
dictionaryExamples: The primary purpose of the meeting is to discuss the future of the company.
The school's new lab will be used for research purposes only.
a multi-purpose kitchen knife
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think the purpose of it was to make the atmosphere more relax[ed]. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: intentionally
dictionaryExamples: I didn't do it on purpose, it was an accident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I didn't do it on purpose; it was dark and I just walked into it. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to have a use
dictionaryExamples: These small community centers serve a very useful purpose.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They introduced meetings at Miss Kenton's parlor which were held every evening and served [the] purpose of discussing house running. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: the feeling of knowing what you want to do
dictionaryExamples: He seems to have lost all sense of purpose.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Emotional stability, a sense of purpose and direction in life, true and deep relationships with the people around us, all these issues are equally, if not more, important than economic security. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: in all the most important ways
dictionaryExamples: To all intents and purposes, the project was a disaster.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To all intents and purposes, the qualities needed to achieve success are based on the same ideas. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a small bag for money, keys, makeup, etc. carried especially by women
dictionaryExamples: Her shoes and purse always match.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think I left my purse at your house last night. Key English Test; A2; Malayalam

sense.def: If you pursue a plan, activity, or situation, you try to do it or achieve it, usually over a long period of time.
dictionaryExamples: She decided to pursue a career in television.
We suspect that our boss is pursuing a hidden agenda.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  I will be shortly pursuing a degree course in computing and I would like to obtain first the entry qualification that is required for the degree course. International English Language Testing System; C1; Khmer

sense.def: when you try to achieve a plan, activity, or situation, usually over a long period of time
dictionaryExamples: the pursuit of pleasure
He left his native country in pursuit of freedom.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nevertheless, despite these claims, the primary motivation for any self-respecting athlete is the pursuit of excellence, attaining cutting-edge skills in their sport. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to move someone or something by pressing them with your hands or body
dictionaryExamples: Can you help me move this table? You push and I'll pull.
The window sticks - you have to push hard to open it.
I tried to push the door open but it was stuck.
Could you push that door shut, please?
A boy had pushed her over in the playground.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Someone push[ed] me into the water. Key English Test; A2; Indonesian

sense.def: to move somewhere by moving someone or something away from you
dictionaryExamples: Please, no pushing! There's plenty of room on the bus for everyone.
She pushed through the crowd.
He pushed past the waiting journalists, refusing to speak to them.
They pushed  their way to the front of the line.

sense.def: to press something
dictionaryExamples: If you push this button, the seat goes back.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was feeling very angry when I pushed the answer button. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to try hard to achieve something or to make someone do something
dictionaryExamples: Local residents are pushing for a traffic light to be put at this busy intersection.
We had to push them to accept our terms, but they finally agreed to the deal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Governments should push young artists to get involve[d] in their work. First Certificate in English; B2; [no L1 data]

sense.def: to make yourself work very hard in order to achieve something
dictionaryExamples: She really pushed herself when she was in school.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Don't push yourself too hard and remember to drink more water. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to try to make someone do something that they do not want to do
dictionaryExamples: My mother pushed me into having ballet lessons.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The biggest help though was my parents who were really understan[ding] and didn't push me too hard into learning English and that [is] why I succe[e]ded. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: when you move someone or something by pressing them with your hands or body
dictionaryExamples: Get on the swing and I'll give you a push.
I gave the door a good push, but it still wouldn't open.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The door was open, so I gave it a push. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: encouragement to make someone do something
dictionaryExamples: I'm sure he'll go, he just needs a little push that's all.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I knew before what I was capable of doing but I really needed a push. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: If you say that something can be done if push comes to shove, you mean that it can be done if the situation becomes so bad that you have to do it.
dictionaryExamples: If push comes to shove, we'll just have to sell the car.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are several option[s] you can choose from when push comes to shove. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Hungarian

sense.def: behaving in an unpleasant way by trying too much to get something or to make someone do something
dictionaryExamples: a pushy salesman
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's bad enough that pushy parents try to turn their children into sports or music stars for the only reason to fulfil[l] their own, never-achieved ambitions. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a game or activity in which you have to put pieces together or answer questions using skill
dictionaryExamples: a jigsaw puzzle
I like to do crossword puzzles.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For present[s] I got a really nice pen, a puzzle and a watch Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: a situation which is very difficult to understand
dictionaryExamples: Scientists have been trying to solve this puzzle for years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As I watched the slow, emerging awareness of humanity, by a chthonic spirit (that of Death itself), coming to terms with the vast contradictions and the harsh, but also bliss-endowed human nature, the soft piano melody internalizing both a child's curiosity before the unknown, as well as an adult's awakening to what his life amounts to, I was thrilled, but also deeply saddened, for I felt that from worthy, meaning-filled fragments of the puzzle that life is, my own piecing together was incomplete: I could not prevent a small sob, which was, almost simultaneously, echoed. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to make someone confused because they do not understand something
dictionaryExamples: I was puzzled by what he said.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Fiona, I was really touched by your concern regarding our daily life at the moment but I was also quite puzzled. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: confused because you do not understand something
dictionaryExamples: He first looked puzzled, then pleased..
I'm a little puzzled by your e-mail.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To the editor, I am puzzled by the report which appeared on yesterday's page 2, concerning the Westfield Music Festival. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: a shape with a square base and four triangular sides that meet to form a point at the top
dictionaryExamples: The pile of stones was shaped like a pyramid.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The King was living in his great palace with a view [of] the biggest pyramid in the village, smaller ones were [situated] around it. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish
